nodes.title: lensmc vs metacal: pipeline independence
nodes.body:
Two independent shear measurement pipelines — lensmc (forward-model PSF fitting) and metacal (metacalibration with sheared images) — process the same galaxies in different ways. If their cross-spectra with CMB κ agree, neither introduces a measurement-specific bias.

The 6-panel spectral overlay (ACT baseline) makes the agreement visible: blue lensmc and orange metacal data points sit on top of each other in every bin, with fractional differences scattering around zero in the sub-panels. The residuals are mostly within ±10% even at noisy bandpowers. Median chi2/dof = 0.14 — suspiciously tight, but expected. The two methods share the *same galaxies* and the *same CMB map*, so their noise is highly correlated. The Knox formula assumes independent noise realizations; applied to the difference of correlated measurements it dramatically overestimates the variance, deflating chi2. This test confirms consistency but has limited discriminating power. A proper test would need a covariance for the difference spectrum accounting for shared noise.

Despite producing consistent cross-spectra, the two methods couple differently to systematic contamination. After template marginalization, lensmc retains 75% of its raw S/N (20σ → 15σ) while metacal retains 69% (19σ → 13σ). The different shear weight maps couple differently to spatially-varying systematics. Both methods give consistent final results, but lensmc is preferable for contamination-sensitive analyses.
nodes.outcome:
Method-comparison plotting is now composite-only: per-bin/per-experiment figure generation was removed from the DAG, and the rule-level claim is driven by a single 6-bin ACT baseline composite plus aggregate evidence. On February 23, 2026 this rerun gave 6 comparisons, median chi2/dof = 1.761, median PTE = 0.139, with 3/6 bins passing PTE >= 0.05 (results/claims/plot_method_comparison/evidence.json). The method agreement remains acceptable, but no longer reads as "too perfect" under the current statistic definition.

The composite still shows tight tracking between lensmc and metacal in each tomographic bin. The pipeline conclusion stays the same: no strong evidence for method-specific shear bias in cross-correlation with CMB kappa. What changed is presentation and statistical calibration: the pipeline now reports one legible figure and one rule-level evidence file, rather than a wildcard gallery and dozens of sidecar evidence files that collaborators do not consume.

This formalization reduces exploration clutter and aligns the rule with the constitution principle that plot outputs should be compressed into collaborator-readable composites. A remaining technical caveat is that the consistency statistic still uses diagonal-error approximations and does not model full shared-noise covariance between methods.

nodes.title: Contamination metric: small per bandpower, dangerous in aggregate
nodes.body:
The contamination metric (Chang et al. 2023, `docs/arxiv/2203.12440`, Eq. A.4.1) quantifies the bias from a systematic map $S$ that correlates with both the tracer field $f$ and CMB lensing $\kappa$:

$$X^{f}_{S}(\ell) = \frac{C^{\kappa S}_\ell \; C^{f S}_\ell}{C^{SS}_\ell}$$

$X$ has the same units as the signal $C^{f\kappa}_\ell$ and can be compared directly to the measurement uncertainty. If a systematic map correlates with both the galaxy field and the CMB reconstruction, the product in the numerator is nonzero and the ratio gives the expected bias per bandpower.

The composite figure shows X(ℓ) for all five systematics crossed with the two baseline CMB reconstructions (ACT and SPT-GMV). Six redshift bins overlaid per panel; gray bands mark 1% and 10% of the Knox uncertainty. Per bandpower, all contamination metrics sit within or below the 1% band. Even galactic extinction, which individually contaminates both κ (chi2 ~ 49–69/20) and shear (chi2/dof up to 9), produces sub-percent per-bandpower bias.

However, per-bandpower smallness does not guarantee negligible integrated bias. Twenty bandpowers each contributing <1% can integrate to a multi-σ shift. The C^{SS} denominator carries noise bias from downgrading sparse systematic maps (nside 16384→2048), making X a lower bound. The [bias budget](.felt/systematic-bias-budget-709ea507.md) integrates over multipoles: stellar density reaches 4.4σ and galactic extinction 3.7σ for ACT. Where the budget flags significant bias, [template marginalization](.felt/template-deprojection-a1621797.md) handles it.
nodes.outcome: Per-bandpower contamination metric X = C^{κS}·C^{fS}/C^{SS} sits below 1% of signal uncertainty for all five systematics across all CMB estimators. However, the integrated bias significance (tapestry:plot_systematic_budget) reaches multi-σ levels for stellar density and galactic extinction — per-bandpower smallness does not guarantee negligible integrated bias.

nodes.title: Estimator comparison
nodes.body:
Two cross-spectrum estimators, same galaxies, same CMB κ, different computational paths: NmtFieldCatalog works directly from galaxy catalogs (bypassing pixelization); NmtField works from HEALPix maps. Agreement validates that map construction introduces no bias.

## Figure

**plot_catalog_vs_map_comparison** — 2-panel (E-mode, B-mode) all-bin figure for each shear method × ACT. Map = filled salmon circles, catalog = open teal squares. Both track each other at all multipoles. chi2/dof ≈ 0.3/20 — extremely low because shared galaxy noise makes quadrature error bars conservative by ~1.8×.

## Resource comparison (SLURM sacct)

| Metric | Map-based (N=366) | Catalog-based (N=111) |
|--------|-------------------|-----------------------|
| Memory avg | 4.5 GB | 4.4 GB (per-bin), 6.1 GB (all-bin) |
| Memory max | 7.2 GB | 6.8 GB (per-bin), 9.0 GB (all-bin) |
| Wall time avg | 55 s | 90 s |
| Wall time max | 2.5 min | 3.3 min |
| Requested | 8 GB | 10 GB (was 64 GB — reduced) |

Catalog is 1.7× slower but same memory class. The 64 GB allocation was massively over-provisioned — reduced to 10 GB (sufficient for all-bin peak of 9 GB).

## Covariance constraint

NmtFieldCatalog has no `get_mask()` method, so NaMaster Gaussian covariance cannot be computed directly from the catalog field. The map-based auxiliary NmtField must still be built for covariance estimation. If covariance computation were decoupled from spectrum computation, catalog could become the default spectrum estimator.
nodes.outcome: Map and catalog estimators are indistinguishable. All-bin E-mode chi2/dof = 0.3/20 (metacal), 0.5/20 (lensmc). max |Δ/σ| < 0.4 everywhere. Catalog is computationally feasible as default (1.7× slower, same memory class), though NaMaster covariance still needs map-based auxiliary fields.

nodes.title: SPT estimators: no foreground bias
nodes.body:
SPT-3G provides four CMB lensing estimator variants with genuinely different foreground sensitivity. PP (polarization-only) is immune to tSZ — the dominant CMB foreground at cluster scales — because tSZ is unpolarized. TT (temperature-only) is maximally sensitive. GMV (minimum-variance) uses all quadratic pairs, combining both channels. Differences between these estimators in cross-correlation with Euclid shear isolate foreground contamination in the lensing reconstruction.

The composite plot shows difference spectra relative to PP: TT minus PP (salmon) and GMV minus PP (teal) for each tomographic bin. This design isolates the tSZ-sensitive component directly — a nonzero TT minus PP would indicate foreground bias entering through the temperature channel. All 24 null tests (2 methods x 6 bins x 2 difference curves) are consistent with zero (median chi2/dof = 0.30, min PTE = 0.927, 0/24 failures at 5%).

The reduced chi2 of 0.30 is expected rather than anomalous. TT, PP, and GMV cross-spectra with the same Euclid shear field share galaxy-side noise — the identical galaxy realization contributes to all three. The difference (e.g. TT minus PP) cancels this common component, but the error bars computed as sqrt(sigma_TT^2 + sigma_PP^2) treat them as independent, double-counting the shared noise that actually cancels. The true variance of the difference is sigma_TT^2 + sigma_PP^2 - 2*cov(TT,PP), which is smaller. This makes the test conservative (overestimated error bars, underestimated chi2) but not invalid — a test that never false-alarms is still a valid null test, just less powerful than it could be. Proper error bars would require the inter-estimator covariance, which we lack.

This means tSZ contamination of the SPT lensing reconstruction does not bias the shear times kappa cross-correlation at current noise levels. The SPT normalization deficit (A_lens approximately 0.70) cannot be explained by foreground leakage — it persists identically across all four estimators, including the foreground-immune PP channel.
nodes.outcome: Redesigned as PP-baseline difference spectra (TT minus PP, GMV minus PP). All 24 null tests consistent with zero: median chi2/dof=0.30 (expected low — shared galaxy noise makes quadrature error bars conservative by ~1.8x), min PTE=0.927, 0/24 failures at 5%. No tSZ foreground bias detected. Evidence at results/claims/plot_spt_estimator_comparison/.

nodes.title: The signal: cross-spectra for 6 bins (γκ + δκ), ACT and SPT
nodes.body:
Hero figure for the Euclid × CMB-κ cross-correlation analysis. Six panels per method (one per tomographic bin) showing ℓ·C_ℓ for ACT DR6 and SPT-3G GMV, with Planck 2018 theory overlay. Three methods (lensmc, metacal, density) produce three figures + three redshift trend panels.

**Density × κ.** Strong detection in every bin. ACT excess S/N: 3.1, 6.3, 6.8, 6.7, 11.9, 9.7σ. SPT: 5.1, 10.7, 10.4, 4.3, 7.9, 15.9σ. Theory tracks data well (A_lens ≈ 1.05 ACT, 0.86 SPT).

**Shear × κ.** After the pol_conv sign convention fix, shear is also strongly detected. LensMC ACT per-bin: 1.5, 0.7, 3.1, 7.1, 12.2, 17.7σ — signal rises sharply with redshift as expected from lensing kernel overlap. A_lens ≈ 0.88 (ACT), 0.69 (SPT). SPT deficit is consistent across all tracers (~15-20% low).

**ACT-SPT consistency.** Both experiments see the same spectral shape across all bins. Detailed chi2 consistency in [ACT vs SPT](.felt/act-vs-spt-cross-spectra-b4181199.md).

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_signal_overview.py`
nodes.outcome: Six-panel hero figure with Planck 2018 theory overlay per method (density, lensmc, metacal). Density x kappa: strong detection across all 6 bins (ACT 3.1-11.9sigma, SPT 4.3-15.9sigma). Shear x kappa: also strong after pol_conv fix — lensmc ACT per-bin 0.7-17.7sigma (rising with redshift), metacal similar pattern. Signal increases with redshift as expected from lensing kernel overlap. Theory overlay shows good agreement for density; shear A_lens ~0.85-0.88 (ACT), ~0.69-0.70 (SPT). Figure widened to 2.5*FW for readability. Evidence output field fixed for tapestry dashboard.

nodes.title: Systematic maps
nodes.body:
We cross-correlate Euclid tracers with 11 potential contaminant maps from the VMPZ-ID mosaic masks pipeline. This figure shows all 11 maps on the RR2 footprint — it is the root of the contamination analysis, giving the reader spatial context before any null test or metric is computed.

## Data source

All maps are produced by the LE3-VMPZ-ID pipeline (Euclid DPDD `le3dpd/id/vmpz-id/dpcards/vmpzid_healpix_infomap.rst:87–128`) and delivered as sparse HEALPix FITS files at nside 16384 (NESTED ordering). We downgrade to nside 2048 to match the analysis resolution (phz_quality is delivered at nside 1024 and is upgraded). Source directory: `inputs/euclid/tr1_pic/VMPZ_ID/MOSAIC_MASKS/`.

VMPZ-ID delivers multiple files per map type — different processing runs, detector components, or bands. For types with many files (PSF: 13, noise: 13), we select one representative file per type (typically the latest timestamp). The file selection is defined in `SYSTEMATIC_MAP_PATHS` in `workflow/Snakefile`.

## Inventory (11 maps)

Organized into four conceptual groups reflecting how they might contaminate cross-correlations.

### A. Astrophysical foregrounds

Maps tracing Galactic structure — physically present on the sky, not artifacts of the survey.

| Key | Physical quantity | Source | Coverage | Summary |
|-----|------------------|--------|----------|---------|
| `stellar_density` | Star number density (stars/deg²) | Gaia catalogs | 79% | Median 0.047, highly structured (galactic latitude gradient) |
| `galactic_extinction` | E(B−V) reddening | Planck dust map (Scaramella+ 2022, A&A 662, A112) | 83% | Median 0.016 mag, smooth gradient across field |
| `star_brightness_mean` | Mean Gaia G-band stellar flux per pixel | Gaia catalogs | 79% | Median 58, enormous dynamic range (5–985 at p10–p90) |

**Stellar density** (`StarNumberDensity` in DPDD:123): surface density of Gaia stars per HEALPix pixel. High stellar density near the Galactic plane increases the rate of star–galaxy misclassification and contaminates aperture photometry through blended profiles. This creates spurious correlations between galaxy density and stellar foreground. For shear, bright stars cause PSF wings and diffraction spikes that locally bias shape measurements.

**Galactic extinction** (`GalacticExtinction` in DPDD:113): E(B−V) reddening from the Planck thermal dust map, per Scaramella+ 2022 (`docs/arxiv/2108.01201`). Dust absorption dims and reddens galaxies, shifting them across photometric redshift bin boundaries and altering the effective selection function. The coherent spatial structure of Galactic dust makes it a low-ℓ contaminant with the same angular scales as the lensing signal.

**Star brightness** (`StarBrightnessMean` in DPDD:125): mean Gaia G-band flux of stars in each pixel. Regions near bright stars suffer from scattered light halos and incomplete masking, reducing galaxy detection completeness. The wide dynamic range (5–985 at p10–p90) means a few very bright stars dominate local contamination.

### B. Survey properties

Maps encoding how the survey observed each region — depth, geometry, and accumulated exposure.

| Key | Physical quantity | Source | Coverage | Summary |
|-----|------------------|--------|----------|---------|
| `exposures` | Number of VIS exposures per pixel | MER Bks Mosaic | 83% | Median 2462, stepped pattern from tile overlaps |
| `zodiacal_light` | Zodiacal background intensity | Scaramella+ 2022 | 83% | Median 1.6×10⁻¹⁸ W/m²/sr, smooth ecliptic gradient |
| `saa` | Solar Aspect Angle | MER Bks Mosaic | 83% | Median 92.5°, smooth spatial gradient |

**Exposures** (`Exposures` in DPDD:107): total number of VIS exposures contributing to each pixel. This is the primary depth proxy — pixels with more exposures have lower noise and deeper photometry, detecting fainter galaxies. The stepped pattern from Euclid's tile overlap strategy creates sharp boundaries in effective depth, which can imprint as galaxy density discontinuities.

**Zodiacal light** (`ZodiacalLight` in DPDD:115): zodiacal dust emission varying with ecliptic latitude and Earth's orbital position. Higher zodiacal background increases the effective noise floor, reducing photometric precision and shifting detection thresholds. At the ~0.01 mag level this affects photo-z accuracy and shear weight assignment.

**Solar Aspect Angle** (`SAA` in DPDD:101): spacecraft orientation relative to the Sun during each observation. SAA determines the thermal state of the spacecraft, which drives optical alignment changes and detector temperature variations. Different SAA values produce slightly different PSF shapes and detector gains. The DPDD also provides Alpha Angle (AA, :103) and Beta Angle (BA, :105) — we use SAA as the primary proxy.

### C. Instrument response

Maps characterizing the detector and optics — how the instrument shaped the recorded signal.

| Key | Physical quantity | Source | Coverage | Summary |
|-----|------------------|--------|----------|---------|
| `psf` | PSF FWHM (arcsec) | MER Bks Mosaic | 80% | Median 0.514, tight range (0.511–0.517 at p10–p90) |
| `noise` | RMS noise per pixel | MER Bks Mosaic | 81% | Median 0.0038, ~30% variation across field |
| `persistence` | Detector persistence fraction | VIS + NIS calibration | 80% | Median 0.21, wide range (0.11–0.38 at p10–p90) |

**PSF FWHM** (`PSF` in DPDD:111): point spread function full width at half maximum from MER background mosaics. PSF variations directly bias galaxy shape measurements through model-fitting residuals. This is the most direct instrumental contaminant for weak lensing — imperfect PSF correction leaves E-mode and B-mode residuals proportional to the PSF anisotropy (cf. DES×SPT Appendix A, Chang+ 2023, `docs/arxiv/2203.12440`).

**Noise RMS** (`Noise` in DPDD:109): root mean square background noise per pixel from MER mosaics. Noise variations change the effective signal-to-noise of shape measurements, modulating shear weights across the footprint. This correlates with both detection completeness and shape measurement precision.

**Persistence** (DPDD; `docs/marseille_wl_talks_md/LE3_VMPZ_ID/LE3_VMPZ_ID.md:17`): residual charge from previous exposures in VIS and NIS detectors. Persistence creates spurious flux that biases both photometry and astrometry. The wide range (0.11–0.38 at p10–p90) suggests large spatial variation in this contaminant.

### D. Derived galaxy properties

Maps constructed from the galaxy catalog itself — these trace the combined effect of all systematics on the final sample.

| Key | Physical quantity | Source | Coverage | Summary |
|-----|------------------|--------|----------|---------|
| `galaxy_number_density` | Galaxy count per pixel | CatRed catalogs | 73% | Median 16.4/pix, traces depth and masking |
| `phz_quality` | Photo-z quality (SEVENTY mean) | CatRed catalogs | 72% | Median 0.27, tail to 0.54 in low-quality regions |

**Galaxy number density** (`GalaxyNumberDensity` in DPDD:117): observed galaxy count per pixel from the CatRed (catalog reduction) pipeline. This is unique among the systematic maps: it measures the same physical field we use as a tracer (galaxy overdensity δ_g). Its spatial variation encodes the net effect of all observational systematics on galaxy detection. The null test C^{δS}_ℓ for this map is expected to fail by construction — galaxy positions are physically correlated with survey depth. The VMPZ-ID ISD (Iterative Systematics Decontamination) and SOM algorithms use this map as their primary decontamination template (`docs/marseille_wl_talks_md/LE3_VMPZ_ID/LE3_VMPZ_ID.md:142–157`).

**Photo-z quality** (`GalaxyRelPhZSeventyMean` in DPDD:121): the mean SEVENTY metric — the fraction of a galaxy's photo-z posterior within ±0.15(1+z) of the point estimate. Lower values indicate broader, less reliable photo-z posteriors. Regions with poor photo-z quality suffer from tomographic bin mixing: galaxies scatter between redshift bins, diluting the lensing signal in a spatially-correlated pattern. This map is delivered at nside 1024 (coarser than the other 10 maps) and is upgraded to nside 2048 for analysis.

### Not included (9 types on disk)

STARBRIGHTNESSRMS, STARBRIGHTNESSSTD (redundant with mean), GALAXYNUMBERDENSITYNEGVISFLUX (subset of galaxy density), GALAXYHFLUXERR, GALAXYRELPHZSEVENTYRMS, GALAXYRELPHZSEVENTYSTD (redundant with mean), AA (ambient angle), BA (background angle), TILE (boundaries). These were inspected and either redundant with included maps or uninformative for cross-correlation systematics.

Coverage fractions are the fraction of pixels within the shear footprint that have nonzero values. The ~20% of pixels without systematic map data correspond to regions outside the VMPZ-ID processing boundary (slightly smaller than the shear footprint).

## Figure

11×2 composite: one row per map, two columns for the north and south RR2 patches (gnomonic projection). Each panel shows the systematic map masked to the shear footprint, with 2nd–98th percentile color scaling. Colormaps alternate between `rocket` and `mako` for visual distinction.

Rule: `plot_systematic_maps` (explorations.smk). Script: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_systematic_maps.py`. Evidence: `cmbx/files/results_claims_plot_systematic_maps_evidence.json`.

## Downstream

These 11 maps feed into three contamination analyses:
- **Systematic null tests** — C^{fS}_ℓ for each tracer × sysmap pair (462 spectra)
- **CMBκ systematic spectra** — C^{κS}_ℓ for each CMB map × sysmap (110 spectra)
- **Contamination metric** — X^f_S = C^{κS} · C^{fS} / C^{SS}, the projected bias per bandpower (Chang+ 2023 Eq. A.4.1)
- **PTE heatmap** — per-bin pass/fail from systematic null tests
- **Contamination overview** — X^f_S summary across all sysmaps
nodes.outcome: All 11 VMPZ-ID systematic maps visualized on the RR2 footprint in a single 11x2 composite (north/south patches). Maps: stellar density, galactic extinction, exposures, zodiacal light, SAA, PSF, noise, persistence, star brightness mean, galaxy number density, photo-z quality. All loaded from sparse FITS nside 16384, downgraded to 2048 (phz_quality at nside 1024 upgraded). Null tests (tracer x sysmap: 462 spectra) and CMBk x sysmap cross-spectra (110 spectra) already computed for all 11 maps. Evidence with per-map statistics (median, p10, p90, frac_nonzero) in results/claims/plot_systematic_maps/evidence.json.

nodes.title: B-mode null test passes: galaxy-side shear systematics are clean
nodes.body:
Weak lensing produces only E-mode shear. Any B×κ signal is either systematic contamination or E→B leakage from the partial-sky geometry. If the [signal](.felt/signal-overview-act-spt-theory-1ae2798f.md) were driven by PSF contamination or shear calibration errors, B-modes would carry the imprint.

They don't. ACT joint chi2/dof = 109.6/120 (PTE = 0.74), SPT joint chi2/dof = 103.3/120 (PTE = 0.86). All 12 bins pass at 5%. B/E amplitude ratios range 0.20–0.96, consistent with E→B leakage at our sky fraction (~4%).

The covariance breakthrough was recognizing that the Knox formula with *observed* BB auto-spectra — which include the leaked E-mode power — correctly captures the leakage-inflated variance. NaMaster's Gaussian covariance uses theoretical BB ≈ 0, underestimating variance by 15–150× and producing false failures. Knox sidesteps this entirely: `Var(C^{Bκ}_b) = C^{BB,obs}_b × C^{κκ}_b / n_modes`. No simulations needed.

This is comparable to [ACT×DES](../docs/papers/2309.04412_act_des_shear/main.tex), which reported PTE = 0.81 using 511 Monte Carlo realizations for covariance.

This test complements the [jackknife null test](.felt/jackknife-null-test-random-sign-e86273e8.md) (random sign-flip destroys correlated signal) and the [simulation null test](.felt/sim-null-test-spt-κ-sims-are-0f7e6bf3.md) (uncorrelated CMB maps). Together they establish: no galaxy-side systematics (B-mode), no correlated artifacts (jackknife), no CMB-side spurious correlations (simulation).
nodes.outcome: B×κ consistent with zero using Knox BB covariance. ACT: chi2/dof=109.6/120, PTE=0.74. SPT: chi2/dof=103.3/120, PTE=0.86. All 12 bins pass at 5%. Knox BB works because observed auto-spectrum includes E→B leakage; NaMaster Gaussian fails (15-150× underestimate). Comparable to ACT×DES sim-based result (PTE=0.81).

nodes.title: Systematic spectra: raw C^{fS}, C^{κS}, C^{SS} contamination ingredients
nodes.body:
The contamination metric X^f_S = C^{κS} · C^{fS} / C^{SS} (Chang+ 2023 Eq. A.4.1, `docs/arxiv/2203.12440`) projects each systematic map's influence into the cross-spectrum. Understanding X requires seeing its three ingredients separately. This figure provides that breakdown: one figure per sysmap (11 total), each with three panels showing C^{fS} (tracer × sysmap), C^{κS} (CMB κ × sysmap), and C^{SS} (sysmap auto-spectrum). All three methods (lensmc, metacal, density) are overlaid per panel with consistent styling from `plot_utils.py`.

## Key features

- **C^{SS} noise floor**: The sysmap auto-spectrum is dominated by pixel noise at ℓ > 500 from downgrading nside 16384 → 2048. This inflates the denominator of X, making the contamination metric a *lower bound* on true contamination. The noise plateau is visible as a flat floor in the third panel of each figure.
- **C^{κS} is small**: CMB κ × sysmap cross-spectra are consistent with zero for most sysmaps, confirming that CMB lensing maps are not significantly contaminated by Euclid-specific systematics.
- **C^{fS} structure**: Tracer × sysmap spectra show real signal for density (galaxy positions correlate with observational depth by construction) and varying levels of correlation for shear methods.
- **Method consistency**: Where lensmc and metacal disagree on C^{fS}, it may indicate a method-specific sensitivity to that systematic.

## Implementation

One figure per sysmap, 11 total. All methods overlaid with ℓ offsets to separate overlapping markers. Left-aligned panel subtitles. Script: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_systematic_spectra.py`. Rule: `plot_systematic_spectra` (explorations.smk, per-sysmap) + `aggregate_systematic_spectra_evidence` (tapestry.smk). Evidence: `results/claims/plot_systematic_spectra/`.
nodes.outcome: Shows the three cross-spectra composing the contamination metric X = C^{κS}·C^{fS}/C^{SS} for each systematic × method × CMB experiment combination. All 6 redshift bins overlaid per panel. Makes the C^{SS} noise bias visible — denominator dominated by pixel noise at high ℓ from nside 16384→2048 downgrade, which makes X a lower bound on true contamination. Created as tapestry node to complete the maps→spectra→metric contamination path. Script: plot_systematic_spectra.py. Evidence in results/claims/plot_systematic_spectra/.

nodes.title: Covariance validation: NaMaster agrees with Knox within 25%
nodes.body:
Two independent covariance estimates — NaMaster Gaussian (harmonic-space, mask-aware) and Knox formula (analytic mode counting) — agree within ~25% for density × CMB κ cross-spectra across all 6 redshift bins and both CMB experiments. This validates the error bars used throughout the analysis.

**NaMaster Gaussian covariance** uses the Improved Narrow Kernel Approximation (INKA) with theory+noise guess spectra: C^{κκ} + N_L for the CMB auto, C^{EE/δδ} + shape/shot noise for the galaxy auto, and C^{fκ}_theory for the cross. This captures mask mode-coupling effects that the Knox formula ignores.

**Knox formula** uses analytic mode counting: Var(C^{ab}_b) = C^{aa}_b · C^{bb}_b / n_modes_b, with n_modes from fsky_eff (Hivon 2002). Independent of mask geometry beyond the effective sky fraction.

The ratio NaMaster/Knox ≈ 1.04 for density (spin-0 × spin-0) and ≈ 1.26 for shear (spin-2 × spin-0, map-based). The >1 ratio is expected: mode coupling from partial sky mixes power between bins, increasing variance beyond what Knox predicts.

**For catalog-based shear** (production default): the NaMaster Gaussian covariance is computed using an auxiliary map-based NmtField. The catalog field measures the spectrum (via NmtFieldCatalog), but the covariance workspace requires map-domain masks that NmtFieldCatalog can't expose. Since covariance depends on mask geometry and auto-spectra (not the measurement method), the map-based covariance is valid for catalog spectra. This gives uniform NaMaster error bars across all probes.

**Bug history**: An interleaved diagonal extraction bug inflated the apparent NaMaster/Knox ratio to ~31× for spin-2 fields. The NaMaster `gaussian_covariance()` output for spin-2 × spin-0 is (2·nbins, 2·nbins) with Eκ and Bκ components interleaved as (bin0_Eκ, bin0_Bκ, bin1_Eκ, ...). Plain `np.diag(cov)[:nbins]` mixed components from wrong bins. Fixed via `extract_covariance_diagonal()` in `nmt_utils.py`.

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_covariance_validation.py`
nodes.outcome: NaMaster Gaussian covariance validated against Knox formula. Density (spin-0): median NaMaster/Knox = 1.04 (range 0.96–2.21, std 0.15). Shear (spin-2, map-based auxiliary field): ~1.26. Role split: NaMaster for plot error bars (captures mode coupling), Knox for S/N annotations and likelihood chi2/PTE/A_lens (avoids coupling matrix artifact at ℓ~2700). Catalog-based shear uses map-based auxiliary NmtField for covariance since NmtFieldCatalog cannot expose masks. Interleaved diagonal extraction bug (31× overestimate) fixed in nmt_utils.extract_covariance_diagonal().

metrics.shear_covariance: NaMaster Gaussian (map-based covariance for catalog estimator)

nodes.title: Euclid RR2 maps
nodes.body:
Euclid RR2 weak lensing and galaxy clustering maps used in the cross-correlation analysis. Two shear measurement pipelines (lensmc, metacal), galaxy density from the GC catalog, and 11 VMPZ-ID systematic maps. The footprint covers ~385 deg² across two spatial patches. Masking follows spectra.make_mask: weights multiplied into the binary footprint, then C2 apodized.

## Shear maps

- **Pipelines**: lensmc, metacal — independent shape measurement methods
- **Per-bin products**: e₁/e₂ shear maps, sum_weights, n_eff
- **All-bin**: union across `config[tomography.bin_ids]`
- **Sign convention**: Euclid e₁ along RA; HEALPix Q along colatitude → [-e₁, e₂] for NaMaster (pol_conv=COSMO)
- **Noise**: NOISE_CL in FITS headers = σ²_comp / n_eff_sr (flat shape noise per component)

## Galaxy density maps

- **Source catalog**: `config[gc_catalog]` (parquet)
- **Bins**: `config[gc_tom_bins]`
- **Products**: δ overdensity + selection mask per bin
- **Density mask is strictly binary**: `build_density_maps.py` sets mask = 1 for every occupied pixel, 0 elsewhere. Only one distinct non-zero value (confirmed bin=3). `make_convergence_mask` then applies `apodize(mask > 0) * mask`, which is apodize(binary) * 1 — the weight factor contributes nothing extra (contrast with shear where `weights=[weight_map]` tapers by varying galaxy weights).
- **Shot noise**: N_ℓ = 1/n̄_sr (constant per mode)

## CMB lensing mask apodization

`make_cmb_mask` calls `nmt.mask_apodization(mask, aposcale, "C2")` on the input. The ACT DR6 baseline mask is already the official 3° cos² apodized lensing mask (Qu+ 2023 Sec 5.3). Applying a second 0.15° C2 pass changes mask pixel values by at most 6.3×10⁻⁴ (rms 2.6×10⁻⁵), zero change in fsky — negligible. This is benign: the long-scale ACT apodization dwarfs the 0.15° second pass.

## Systematic maps

11 VMPZ-ID maps at nside 16384 (NESTED), downgraded to analysis nside at load time:
stellar_density, galactic_extinction, exposures, zodiacal_light, saa, psf, noise, persistence, star_brightness_mean, galaxy_number_density, phz_quality

## Tomographic binning

`config[tomography.n_bins]` bins (IDs: `config[tomography.bin_ids]`). Shear n(z) from `config[nz.wl]`; density n(z) from `config[nz.gc]`.

## Weight masking

spectra.make_mask(): binary footprint × weights, then apodize. Scale: `config[cross_correlation.aposcale]`°. For density, weights=[binary mask], so C2 apodization acts on a hard edge — visible rolloff at the footprint boundary. For shear, weights=[sum_weights], so the taper is smoothed by varying galaxy counts before apodization.

## Estimator

`config[cross_correlation.estimator]`: catalog (NmtFieldCatalog, bypasses map-making) or map (NmtField).

## Apodization audit

Visualized in `cmbx/files/results_claims_euclid_density_apodization_euclid_density_apodization.png` (rule `plot_euclid_density_apodization`). Rows: density raw, density post-apod, ACT raw, ACT post-double-apod.
nodes.outcome: Two-figure documentation: unmasked (shear weights + density contrast, 2x2 north/south) and apodized (C2 masks showing estimator support). Shear weights range 254-1391, density contrast in [-1,1]. Apodized density mask is binary with 9-arcmin edge taper; shear mask shows continuous weight gradients. Both figures at results/claims/euclid_rr2_maps/.

nodes.title: CMB lensing maps
nodes.body:
CMB lensing convergence (κ) maps from ACT DR6 and SPT-3G used as the mass tracer in cross-correlations with Euclid. κ is the projected matter density along the line of sight, reconstructed from CMB temperature and polarization via quadratic estimators. Both experiments provide κ maps, masks, noise curves, and simulations.

## What κ is

Lensing convergence κ(n̂) = -½ ∇² φ(n̂), where φ is the lensing potential. Proportional to the projected matter density weighted by the lensing kernel. Spin-0 field.

## Shared conventions

- All κ maps at nside `config[nside]` (downgraded from native resolution at data prep time, not runtime)
- Masks are pre-apodized by the experiments; we apply additional `config[cross_correlation.aposcale]`° C2 apodization via make_cmb_mask
- Noise per mode (N_L) provided by each experiment — used for Knox formula and theory comparison

## Experiments

Two baselines for cross-correlation: ACT DR6 and SPT-3G winter GMV. SPT also provides TT, PP, MV estimator variants for consistency checks. Details in child fibers.
nodes.outcome: Two-row Wiener-filtered kappa map: ACT DR6 (top, +/-0.033) and SPT-3G GMV (bottom, +/-0.061). ACT covers both RR2 patches, SPT only south. SPT amplitude range ~2x ACT reflects higher noise floor. Large-scale lensing structure visible in both. Figure at results/claims/cmb_lensing_maps/cmb_lensing_maps.png.

nodes.title: ACT DR6 lensing
nodes.body:
ACT DR6 CMB lensing convergence map — the primary wide-area CMB lensing dataset in this analysis. 9,400 deg² (fsky ≈ 0.23), reconstructed from temperature and polarization using the minimum-variance quadratic estimator (Qu+ 2023, Madhavacheril+ 2023).

## Data products

- **κ map**: kappa_map_data_act_dr6_lensing_v1_baseline.fits (nside 2048)
- **Mask**: mask_act_dr6_lensing_v1_healpix_nside_2048_baseline.fits (downgraded from official nside=4096 release). 3° cosine-squared apodization applied by ACT (Qu+ 2023 Sec. 5.3; docs/arxiv/2304.05202_act_dr6_lensing_power/main.tex:453). ~20% of nonzero pixels < 1.
- **Noise curve**: N_L_kk_act_dr6_lensing_v1_baseline.txt (provided in release)
- **Filter**: kappa_filter_act_dr6_lensing_v1_baseline.txt

## Overlap with Euclid RR2

~261 deg² (mask > 0.95 threshold). Euclid footprint is fully contained within ACT.

## References

- Qu+ 2023 (2304.05202): DR6 lensing power spectrum. TeX: docs/arxiv/2304.05202_act_dr6_lensing_power/main.tex
- Madhavacheril+ 2023 (2304.05203): DR6 lensing map and cosmological parameters
nodes.outcome: Two-figure documentation: Wiener-filtered kappa on sky (both patches, +/-0.033 range) and apodized product (kappa x ACT mask x Euclid mask, showing estimator support with smooth C2 edge rolloff). ACT covers 261 deg2 overlap with Euclid. Figures at results/claims/act_dr6_lensing/.

nodes.title: SPT-3G winter lensing
nodes.body:
SPT-3G winter field CMB lensing convergence maps — the deep, small-area CMB lensing dataset. ~1,550 deg² (mask > 0.95), four estimator variants sharing the same footprint.

## Estimator variants

- **GMV** (generalized minimum variance): baseline, highest SNR
- **PP** (polarization-only): least biased by foregrounds, key cross-check
- **TT** (temperature-only): most sensitive to tSZ/CIB contamination
- **MV** (minimum variance): standard MV combination

GMV and PP are the primary baselines for cross-correlation. TT and MV are consistency checks (SPT estimator comparison node).

## Data products (per estimator)

- **κ map**: k{gmv,tt,pp,mv}_fid_052425_0.fits
- **Mask**: mask2048_border_apod_mask_threshold0.1_allghz_dense.fits (shared, pre-apodized, ~31% of nonzero pixels < 1)
- **Simulations**: 11 sims per estimator (1 Gaussian + 10 Agora), independent κ realizations
- **N₀**: placeholder from auto-minus-cross of independent sims (approximate). Proper N₀ to come from SPT.

## Overlap with Euclid RR2

~115 deg² (mask > 0.95 threshold). Smaller overlap than ACT but deeper per-mode sensitivity.

## Open questions

- 24% deficit in SPT×Euclid relative to ACT×Euclid (see spt-deficit-characterization-6b724e41)
- SPT mask: pre-apodized; provenance not yet documented from SPT papers
- Proper N₀ needed from SPT (current is approximate)
nodes.outcome: Two-figure documentation: Wiener-filtered GMV kappa on sky (south patch only — north patch blank, +/-0.062 range) and apodized product showing 115 deg2 estimator support in the Euclid-SPT triple overlap. Noisier than ACT (amplitude range ~2x), but real lensing structure visible. Figures at results/claims/spt_winter_lensing/.

Installed TinyTeX directly into writable container (/usr/local/TinyTeX) and linked TeX binaries into /usr/local/bin so text.usetex works in Snakemake container jobs without bashrc/bind hacks. nodes.title: Introduction
nodes.body:
Cross-correlating CMB lensing convergence with the shapes and positions of photometric galaxies probes the growth of large-scale structure across cosmic time, testing ΛCDM with independent observables from two entirely different physical effects. This analysis measures C_ℓ^{γκ} and C_ℓ^{δκ} between Euclid RR2 weak lensing shear / galaxy density and CMB lensing convergence from ACT DR6 and SPT-3G (winter), across 6 tomographic bins.

**Headline result**: Both cross-correlations are detected at high significance with ACT DR6 after resolving the Euclid position-angle sign convention (`pol_conv="EUCLID"` → [-e1, +e2] for NaMaster; see `shear-sign-convention-test-b751c2ca`). Galaxy density × CMB-κ: A_lens = 1.049 ± 0.063 (ACT, χ²/dof = 1.07), 0.857 ± 0.050 (SPT). Shear × CMB-κ: A_lens = 0.880 ± 0.052 (lensmc × ACT, 17σ), 0.850 ± 0.055 (metacal × ACT, 15σ), 0.694 ± 0.045 (lensmc × SPT), 0.697 ± 0.048 (metacal × SPT). After marginalizing over 11 systematic contamination templates: density A_lens = 0.986 ± 0.122 (ACT), 0.812 ± 0.122 (SPT); shear A_lens = 0.824 ± 0.095 (lensmc × ACT), 0.780 ± 0.097 (metacal × ACT). SPT shows a persistent 15–20% amplitude deficit across all tracers — a CMB-side normalization issue under investigation (`spt-deficit-characterization-6b724e41`).

**Motivation**: CMB lensing × cosmic shear is insensitive to additive shear systematics (which don't correlate with the CMB) and CMB lensing multiplicative biases — making it a robust, nearly model-independent probe of the projected matter distribution at z ~ 0.3–1.5. Euclid's wide southern survey provides the galaxy data; ACT and SPT provide CMB lensing over overlapping patches of 261 deg² and 115 deg² respectively.

**Comparator analyses**: 
- DES × ACT DR6: Qu+ 2023 (`docs/papers/2309.04412_act_des_shear/main.tex`).
- DES × SPT methods: Chang+ 2022 (`docs/papers/2203.12439_des_spt_planck_methods/main.tex`).
- DES × SPT correlations: Omori+ 2022 (`docs/papers/2203.12440_des_spt_planck_correlations/main.tex`).
- DES × SPT 2026 update: `cmbx/files/docs_papers_des_spt_shearxlensing_2026_shearXlensing_20260202.pdf`.
- ACT DR6 lensing power spectrum: Madhavacheril+ 2024 (`cmbx/files/docs_arxiv_2304.05202_act_dr6_lensing_power_main.tex`).
- SPT-3G winter lensing: `cmbx/files/docs_papers_spt_winter_lensing_apssamp.tex`.

**Collaboration**: SPT-Euclid MoU (DR1-KP-CMBX-3/2) — see [MOU proposal](.felt/spt-euclid-mou-collaboration-6de6bc54.md). CMBX-SWG is coordinating with WL-SWG on blinding; CMBX is listed as a potential unblinding authority. People: Cail Daley (data), Margherita Lembo (co-lead, gctools), Louis Legrand (co-lead, likelihood), Giulio Fabbian (SWG science lead), Emma Ayçoberry.

nodes.title: Data
nodes.body:
Three surveys on the southern sky, cross-correlated where their footprints overlap. All maps at HEALPix nside=2048 (RING), masked with C2 apodization at 0.15 deg. Overlap areas (mask > 0.95): ACT × Euclid 261 deg², SPT × Euclid 115 deg², triple overlap 74 deg².

**Euclid RR2 weak lensing.** Catalog `rr2_v2_1_wl_031224`: ~50M galaxies over 385 deg² effective footprint, split into 6 tomographic bins (mean redshift 0.52--1.72). Two independent shear pipelines — LensMC (forward-model) and Metacal (image-differencing) — provide e1/e2 per galaxy. Galaxy density from GC catalog (`catalogRR2_v2_GC_031124`): ~30M galaxies in 6 bins (mean z 0.31--0.89). Eleven VMPZ-ID systematic maps at nside 16384 track observational systematics (stellar density, galactic extinction, PSF, noise, persistence, etc.). Caveat: RR2 WL calibration columns (multiplicative bias m, additive bias c, calibrated weights) are all NaN — no shear calibration applied.

**ACT DR6 CMB lensing.** Convergence (κ) reconstructed via minimum-variance quadratic estimator from temperature and polarization (Qu+ 2023, Madhavacheril+ 2023). Total sky 9,400 deg² (fsky ≈ 0.23). The official apodized mask has a 3 deg cosine-squared rolloff. Noise power spectrum N_L provided per mode; Wiener-filtered κ map is the baseline product.

**SPT-3G winter CMB lensing.** Deep but narrow: ~1,550 deg² total, 115 deg² overlap with Euclid. Four estimator variants sharing the same footprint: GMV (baseline, highest S/N), TT (temperature-only, most tSZ-sensitive), PP (polarization-only, foreground-free), MV (standard minimum variance). Comparing TT−PP and GMV−PP isolates potential foreground bias. Approximate N₀ computed from auto-minus-cross of 11 simulations; proper noise curves pending from SPT. κ amplitude range ±0.062 (roughly 2× noisier than ACT).

**Redshift distributions.** n(z) from `RR2_v2_Nz_WL_C2020_sel_pv.fits` (3000-point grid, z = 0–6, sum-normalized per bin). Theory C_ℓ uses raw FITS n(z) — smoothing procedure not yet confirmed.

Sub-nodes: Euclid RR2 maps (`euclid-rr2-maps-0d4db3db`), CMB lensing maps (`cmb-lensing-maps-e7e9436c`) → ACT DR6 (`act-dr6-lensing-e4a3eae9`), SPT-3G winter (`spt-3g-winter-lensing-ab712d17`), Euclid n(z) (`euclid-n-z-d8d52b17`), shared conventions (`maps-shared-conventions-and-c4fac8e3`).

nodes.title: Methods
nodes.body:
Angular cross-power spectra are estimated via the NaMaster pseudo-Cℓ formalism (Alonso+ 2019), which corrects for mode-coupling induced by partial-sky masks through a coupling matrix and decouples into bandpowers. This section describes the estimators, masking, and covariance used throughout the analysis.

## Pseudo-Cℓ estimation

We measure cross-power spectra C^{fκ}_ℓ between Euclid tracers (shear γ or galaxy density δ) and CMB lensing convergence κ. All spectra are computed at nside=2048, lmax=3000, using 20 linearly-spaced bandpowers.

### Map-based estimator (production)

The production estimator operates on HEALPix maps. Shear maps enter NaMaster as spin-2 fields (`NmtField` with `pol_conv="IAU"`, lmax=3000); density overdensity maps and CMB κ maps enter as spin-0 fields. The mode-coupling matrix is computed from the apodized mask geometry and cached via `joblib` hash of the mask alms — the expensive coupling matrix computation happens once per mask pair and is reused across tomographic bins and shear methods.

For shear: `make_field([e1_map, e2_map], mask, spin=2, pol_conv="IAU")`. For density: `make_field([delta_map], mask, spin=0)`. For CMB κ: `make_field([kappa_map], cmb_mask, spin=0)`.

Rules: `compute_cross_spectrum` (spectra.smk). Library: `dr1_cmbx.eDR1data.spectra` — `make_field()`, `get_spectrum()`, `get_workspace()`.

### Catalog-based estimator (validation)

The catalog estimator bypasses map-making entirely: `NmtFieldCatalog` takes individual galaxy positions and ellipticities as a point cloud and computes spherical harmonic transforms in position space. This eliminates pixelization artifacts. Agreement with the map estimator — median bandpower correlation r=0.998, A_lens consistent within 1σ for every bin — confirms that map construction introduces no measurable bias.

Covariance for the catalog path uses an auxiliary map-based `NmtField` from the same shear maps, since `NmtFieldCatalog.get_mask()` raises ValueError. The covariance depends on mask geometry and auto-spectra, not the measurement method, so this is valid.

Rule: `compute_catalog_cross_spectrum` (explorations.smk). ~8 GB, 3-4 min/job at lmax=3000.

## Masking and apodization

Partial-sky pseudo-Cℓ estimation requires apodized masks to suppress spectral ringing from sharp survey boundaries. Four input masks — Euclid shear (continuous weights × binary footprint), Euclid density (binary), ACT DR6 (pre-apodized with 3° cosine-squared rolloff), and SPT-3G (border-apodized) — are C2-apodized at 0.15 rad (~8.6°), producing 10 mask products: 4 individual + 6 pairwise cross-products.

Shear masks: `footprint × weight_map → C2(0.15)`. The continuous weight map creates a smooth taper. Density masks: binary footprint → C2(0.15), producing only a ~9 arcmin edge taper. CMB masks: pre-apodized by experiment + additional 0.15° C2 pass (negligible for ACT, shapes SPT border).

Effective sky fractions (Hivon fsky_eff): shear×ACT 0.70%, shear×SPT 0.32%, density×ACT 0.67%, density×SPT 0.30%.

Rules: `build_rr2_apodized_masks`, `build_apodized_pair_masks` (maps.smk). Library: `make_mask()`, `make_cmb_mask()`.

## Covariance estimation

Two independent estimates validate each other:

**Knox formula** (primary for all χ²/PTE/S/N): `Var(C^{ab}_b) = C^{aa}_b · C^{bb}_b / n_modes_b` where `n_modes = Σ(2ℓ+1) · fsky_eff` with `fsky_eff = <w1·w2>² / <w1²·w2²>` (Hivon+ 2002 Eq. 17). Analytic, immune to coupling matrix numerics.

**NaMaster Gaussian** (error bars in plots): Uses the Improved Narrow Kernel Approximation (INKA) with theory+noise guess spectra. For spin-2 × spin-0, output is `(2·nbins, 2·nbins)` with interleaved E/B components — extracted via `extract_covariance_block` to the `(nbins, nbins)` E-mode block. Known artifact: last bandpower (ℓ≈2700) has near-zero variance from coupling matrix numerics (~1000× below Knox). This is why Knox is used for quantitative inference.

NaMaster/Knox ratio: 1.04 median for density (spin-0), ~1.26 for shear (spin-2). The >1 ratio reflects mode coupling from partial sky mixing power between bins — expected behavior.

## Implementation

Core library: `dr1_cmbx.eDR1data.spectra` (`cmbx/files/code_dr1_cmbx_src_dr1_cmbx_eDR1data_spectra.py`). Key functions: `make_mask()`, `make_field()`, `make_catalog_field()`, `get_spectrum()`, `map2cls()`, `get_workspace()`, `compute_knox_variance()`, `extract_covariance_block()`.

Snakemake rules: `compute_cross_spectrum` (production), `compute_catalog_cross_spectrum` (validation), `build_rr2_apodized_masks`, `build_apodized_pair_masks`, `compute_systematic_cross_spectrum`.

nodes.title: Validation
nodes.body:
Validation proceeds through four pillars: theory consistency (do the measured spectra match Planck 2018 ΛCDM?), cross-experiment and cross-pipeline consistency (do ACT and SPT agree? lensmc and metacal?), null tests (jackknife, simulation, B-mode), and systematic contamination analysis (11 VMPZ-ID maps, bias budget, harmonic-space contamination metric, and template marginalization).

Both tracers pass validation for ACT after the Euclid position-angle sign convention fix (`pol_conv="EUCLID"` → [-e1, +e2] for NaMaster). Density × κ: A_lens = 1.049 ± 0.063 (χ²/dof = 1.07, PTE = 0.28); all null tests consistent with zero; template marginalization yields A_lens = 0.986 ± 0.122. Shear × κ: A_lens = 0.880 ± 0.052 (lensmc × ACT, 17σ), 0.850 ± 0.055 (metacal × ACT, 15σ) — detected with chi2/dof = 0.92 and 0.97 respectively. SPT shows a 15–20% deficit for all tracers (density A_lens = 0.857 ± 0.050, lensmc = 0.694 ± 0.045, metacal = 0.697 ± 0.048) that persists after template marginalization — a CMB-side normalization issue under investigation (`spt-deficit-characterization-6b724e41`).

Fourteen nodes populate this section, organized by concern. The density systematic budget is severe (galactic extinction up to 12.6σ bias for ACT, stellar density 6.3σ) — template marginalization is mandatory for density. Shear systematics are clean (median χ²/dof = 1.29, 74% pass). B-mode covariance is approximate: NaMaster Gaussian underestimates BB variance at partial sky by 15–150× due to E→B leakage (`namaster-gaussian-covariance-9373b1fa`). Template marginalization is implemented via Fisher matrix joint fit in `evaluate_deprojected_likelihood`.

nodes.title: Results
nodes.body:
Both cross-correlations — galaxy density × CMB κ and cosmic shear × CMB κ — are detected at high significance with ACT DR6, validating the full Euclid × CMB lensing pipeline against Planck 2018 ΛCDM. SPT-3G shows a persistent 15–20% amplitude deficit across all tracers, pointing to a CMB-side normalization issue rather than a galaxy-side problem.

**Density × κ.** A_lens = 1.049 ± 0.063 (ACT, χ²/dof = 1.07), 0.857 ± 0.050 (SPT). ACT is fully consistent with Planck 2018 (A_lens = 1). Per-bin Knox S/N: 3.1, 6.3, 6.8, 6.7, 11.9, 9.7 (ACT). Template marginalization over 11 systematic maps yields A_lens = 0.986 ± 0.122 (ACT), 0.812 ± 0.122 (SPT) — density is robust to systematic contamination despite severe galaxy-density correlations with observational depth.

**Shear × κ.** A_lens = 0.880 ± 0.052 (lensmc × ACT, 17σ), 0.850 ± 0.055 (metacal × ACT, 15σ) with χ²/dof = 0.92 and 0.97. Both shear pipelines agree within 1σ. Prior to the Euclid position-angle sign convention fix (`pol_conv="EUCLID"` → [-e1, +e2]), A_lens ≈ 0.06 — the sign bug was the dominant systematic, now resolved (`shear-sign-convention-test-b751c2ca`). SPT shear: A_lens = 0.694 ± 0.045 (lensmc), 0.697 ± 0.048 (metacal). Deprojected (template marginalization): lensmc × ACT 0.824 ± 0.095, metacal × ACT 0.780 ± 0.097.

**Per-bin structure.** Signal rises with redshift as expected from the CMB lensing kernel. Shear per-bin S/N: 1.5, 0.7, 3.1, 7.1, 12.2, 17.7 (lensmc × ACT) — high-z bins dominate. Theory comparison χ²/dof degrades with z for shear (1.3 at bin 1 → 17 at bin 6) while density ≈ 1.0 everywhere — a z-dependent shear calibration issue, possibly related to the unvalidated RR2 multiplicative bias correction (m/c columns all NaN, `rr2-wl-catalog-calibration-5ee5e957`).

**SPT deficit.** The 15–20% amplitude deficit is consistent across density, lensmc, and metacal — ruling out galaxy-side causes. Under investigation (`spt-deficit-characterization-6b724e41`). The approximate SPT N₀ from auto-minus-cross may contribute.

nodes.title: Euclid catalog
nodes.body:
The Euclid RR2 weak lensing and galaxy clustering catalogs. WL: ~50M galaxies measured with lensmc and metacal shear pipelines, 6 tomographic bins defined by photometric redshift. GC: ~30M galaxies, 6 bins spanning z̄ ≈ 0.31–0.89 — shallower than WL (z̄ ≈ 0.52–1.72), reflecting the photometric selection for clustering. Catalog inputs: `euclid/catalogs/rr2_v2_1_wl_031224/` (WL), `euclid/catalogs/catalogRR2_v2_GC_031124.parquet` (GC). Both feed into map-building rules producing the HEALPix maps in [Euclid RR2 maps](.felt/euclid-rr2-maps-0d4db3db.md).

**Figure** (`euclid_nz_overview.png`): Two-panel plot of n(z) for WL (left) and GC (right). Each panel shows 6 tomographic bins as filled curves, normalized to unit area (∫n(z)dz = 1) over a 3000-point grid from z=0 to z=6. Curves drawn from the theoretical pipeline n(z) stored in `RR2_v2_Nz_WL/GC_C2020_sel_pv.fits` (columns BIN_ID, MEAN_REDSHIFT, N_Z). Mean redshift annotated per bin in the legend.

**Open: n(z) smoothing** — the theoretical n(z) arrays from the FITS files are noisy/jagged in the tails. The correct smoothing procedure for use in the theory C_ℓ calculation is not yet confirmed. Check Slack for the established RR2 convention (Margherita / WL-SWG n(z) thread). Until resolved, theory C_ℓ uses the raw FITS n(z).

nodes.title: Apodization Layer
nodes.body:
Partial-sky pseudo-Cℓ estimation requires apodized masks to suppress spectral ringing from sharp survey boundaries. This layer takes four input masks — Euclid shear (continuous weights × binary footprint), Euclid density (binary), ACT DR6 (pre-apodized with 3° cosine-squared rolloff), and SPT-3G (border-apodized) — and produces the 10 C2-apodized products needed by the estimators: 4 individual masks plus all 6 pairwise cross-products (shear×ACT, shear×SPT, density×ACT, density×SPT, ACT×SPT, shear×density). The apodization kernel is C2 at 0.15 rad (~8.6°), following gctools conventions. Effective sky fractions are small: shear×ACT 0.70%, shear×SPT 0.32%, density×ACT 0.67%, density×SPT 0.30% — driven by the intersection of Euclid's ~385 deg² RR2 footprint with the CMB lensing patches.

Two Snakemake rules implement this: `build_rr2_apodized_masks` (the 10 shared masks) and `build_apodized_pair_masks` (per-bin per-CMB pair masks for the estimators). Downstream: [Map Harmonic Estimator](.felt/map-based-harmonic-space-5f227b0f.md) consumes these masks via `make_mask()` and `make_cmb_mask()` in `dr1_cmbx.eDR1data.spectra`.
nodes.outcome: Apodization infrastructure complete: build_rr2_apodized_masks produces 10 C2-apodized mask FITS (shear, density, ACT, SPT, and all pairwise cross-products) from 4 input masks. Effective fsky: shear×ACT 0.70%, shear×SPT 0.32%, density×ACT 0.67%, density×SPT 0.30%. Shear support_fraction (0.93%) exceeds effective_fraction anomalously — weight variability inflates the support relative to Hivon effective area; density (binary weights) shows the expected support > effective ordering. Per-bin per-CMB pair masks built by build_apodized_pair_masks. Memory tuned: density_map at 4–24 GB (bin-dependent), rr2_apodized at 24 GB. Remaining open question: whether 0.15° aposcale is optimal (tracked in choose-additional-c2-aposcale-5cdf0511).

nodes.title: Wiener filter validation
nodes.body:
Two-panel diagnostic for the CMB lensing noise regime. Panel (a): C_ℓ^map for ACT/SPT and residuals |C_ℓ^map − C_ℓ^{κκ,theory}| against Planck 2018 theory, showing where signal exceeds noise. Panel (b): theory-informed Wiener filter W(ℓ) from published noise curves.

The filter quantifies the ℓ range where cross-correlation is signal-dominated. For ACT, this is ℓ < 145; for SPT, the N₀ is too noisy from only 11 sims to characterize cleanly, but the trend is similar. This sets expectations for the bandpower S/N in the cross-spectra: most information comes from ℓ < 200.

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_wiener_filter_validation.py`
nodes.outcome: Theory-informed Wiener filter W(ℓ) = C_ℓ^{κκ} / (C_ℓ^{κκ} + N_ℓ) using published ACT N_L and computed SPT N₀ (11 sims). ACT peaks at W≈0.7 near ℓ~60, crosses 0.5 at ℓ~145. SPT N₀ noisy at low ℓ (only 11 sims). Both experiments noise-dominated at ℓ>200.

metrics.finding: Theory-informed Wiener filter W(l) crosses 0.5 at l~145 (ACT) and l~5 (SPT). Both maps are noise-dominated at all l for cross-correlation purposes; SPT retains more signal at low l due to lower reconstruction noise.

nodes.title: Contamination overview created
nodes.body:
The contamination overview is the hero figure of the systematic validation — a single plot showing X^f_S = C^{κS} · C^{fS} / C^{SS} (Chang+ 2023, `docs/arxiv/2203.12440`, Eq. A.4.1) for all 11 systematic maps across both tracer types. X^f_S has the same units as the signal C^{fκ}, so a direct comparison tells us how much each systematic biases the measurement per bandpower.

## Layout

2 columns (density, shear) × 11 rows (sysmaps). Density column shows ACT + SPT (2 curves). Shear column shows lensmc×ACT, metacal×ACT, lensmc×SPT, metacal×SPT (4 curves). Each subplot has its own title: "{Sysmap} × {Tracer}". Methods are distinguished by both linestyle (solid=lensmc, dashed=metacal) and marker (circle=lensmc, square=metacal); color encodes CMB experiment (salmon=ACT, teal=SPT) from the shared `COLORS` dict.

## Error bars

Propagated from Knox formula: σ²(X) is computed from the Knox covariance of C^{κS} and C^{fS}. C^{SS} is noise-biased at high ℓ (see `systematic-spectra-raw-c-fs-c-3d65264d`), so X is a lower bound on true contamination.

## Implementation

Rule: `plot_contamination_overview` (explorations.smk, localrule — reads pre-computed NPZ). Script: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_contamination_overview.py`. Evidence: `cmbx/files/results_claims_plot_contamination_overview_evidence.json`. Polished in `contamination-overview-polished-f12338e4`.
nodes.outcome: Contamination overview X^f_S hero plot: 2x11 grid (density vs shear columns, 11 sysmap rows). Per-subplot titles "{Sysmap} x {Tracer}", FW-scale columns, margins in inches. Methods distinguished by linestyle (solid/dashed) AND marker (circle/square), color encodes CMB experiment (ACT salmon, SPT teal). Y-axis label on left column only. Legend in top-right panel. Script: plot_contamination_overview.py (localrule). Evidence: results/claims/plot_contamination_overview/.

nodes.title: PTE heatmap created
nodes.body:
A single-glance diagnostic showing which systematic × tracer × tomographic bin combinations pass the null test. The heatmap displays PTE (probability to exceed) from the χ² test of C^{fS}_ℓ = 0 for each cell. Red cells (PTE < 0.05) indicate the measured cross-spectrum is unlikely to be noise; blue cells (PTE > 0.95) would indicate anomalously low scatter. This complements the contamination overview (X^f_S) by testing whether the *tracer* side of the contamination chain is consistent with zero, independently of the CMB κ side.

## Layout

11 rows (sysmaps) × 18 columns (3 tracers × 6 tomographic bins). Colormap: `vlag` (diverging, red–blue) with saturated tails — PTE < 0.05 maps to the same extreme red (all failures identical), PTE > 0.95 to extreme blue, interior [0.05, 0.95] spans the full color range. Cells annotated by PTE value (2 decimal places). Missing data in light gray.

## Results

- **Density**: 0/66 pass (all PTE = 0.00). Expected — galaxy positions physically correlate with survey depth, stellar density, etc. This is not a failure of the analysis; it confirms the maps contain real structure.
- **LensMC**: 56/66 pass (85%). Failures in galactic extinction, galaxy number density, and persistence at specific bins (2, 5, 6).
- **Metacal**: 57/66 pass (86%). Similar failure pattern to lensmc.

## Caveat

Error bars use NaMaster Gaussian covariance, which is not yet validated for tracer × sysmap cross-spectra. The PTE pass/fail rates may reflect error bar mis-estimation rather than true contamination. This heatmap should be read as a preliminary diagnostic, not a definitive verdict. See `namaster-gaussian-covariance-9373b1fa` for covariance validation status.

## Implementation

Rule: `plot_pte_heatmap` (explorations.smk, localrule). Script: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_pte_heatmap.py`. Evidence: `cmbx/files/results_claims_plot_pte_heatmap_evidence.json`.
nodes.outcome: New rule plot_pte_heatmap: 11x18 matshow (sysmaps x tracers*bins). Density 0/66 pass (all PTE=0.00, expected — galaxy positions correlate with survey depth). LensMC 56/66 pass (85%). Metacal 57/66 pass (86%). Shear failures scattered across galactic extinction, galaxy_number_density, persistence bins 2/5/6. Error bars not yet validated — PTE may reflect covariance mis-estimation.

fibers.title: Shear non-detection
fibers.body:
## Shear × κ is not detected

### Finding

The shear × CMB lensing cross-correlation is **not detected** in any tomographic bin, for either CMB experiment, for both shear methods, and for both map and catalog estimators. This is the most important open issue in the pipeline.

**A_lens per bin (lensmc × ACT, Knox variance):**

| Bin | A_lens (map) | A_lens (metacal map) |
|-----|-------------|---------------------|
| 1   | 0.03 ± 0.27 | 0.10 ± 0.26        |
| 2   | 0.10 ± 0.21 | -0.09 ± 0.23       |
| 3   | 0.18 ± 0.17 | 0.18 ± 0.19        |
| 4   | 0.17 ± 0.13 | 0.09 ± 0.14        |
| 5   | 0.02 ± 0.09 | 0.16 ± 0.10        |
| 6   | 0.04 ± 0.07 | 0.10 ± 0.07        |

**Joint A_lens (all consistent with zero):**

| | ACT | SPT |
|---|---|---|
| Lensmc | 0.062 ± 0.045 (S/N = −0.8) | −0.053 ± 0.040 (S/N = 0.5) |
| Metacal | 0.108 ± 0.048 (S/N = −0.1) | −0.009 ± 0.044 (S/N = 0.6) |

All four combinations 18–24σ from unity. ACT and SPT agree: no shear signal.

**Meanwhile, density × κ is strongly detected:** A_lens = 1.049 ± 0.063 (ACT), 0.857 ± 0.050 (SPT).

### Systematic investigation (iteration 2026-02-25)

#### Ruled out

1. **Map-making bug** — Catalog estimator (NmtFieldCatalog, bypasses pixelization) gives the same A ≈ 0.1.
2. **Method-specific issue** — Both lensmc AND metacal give A ≈ 0.1. Methods are independent (forward-model vs metacal).
3. **NaMaster spin-2 bug** — Density (spin-0 × spin-0) works, and the binned coupling matrix roundtrip is perfect (amplification = 1.0 ± 2e-14).
4. **pol_conv issue** — IAU convention passes e1, e2 unflipped to NaMaster. A sign error would produce a negative B-mode, not suppress E-mode to zero. B-modes scatter around zero as expected.
5. **Theory prediction wrong** — Independent CCL computation (with bbks transfer) matches stored eDR1like.Theory within 2-6%. Theory at ℓ=100 for bin3: 8.8e-9 (stored) vs 9.0e-9 (direct).
6. **Bandpower window normalization** — E→E window sums per bin: 1.00 ± 0.01 (first bin 1.075, all others within 0.1%).
7. **Catalog blinding** — Marseille JC1 summary (Oct 2025): "cross-correlations (including the mixes we rely on) stay unblinded."
8. **Multiplicative bias** — LensMC talk reports |m| ~ 2×10⁻³ from simulations. (1+m)² ≈ 1 — can't explain 90% suppression.
9. **Galaxy resolution** — `she_metacal_r2/(r2+psf_r2)` = 0.74 (well-resolved). S/N median = 92. These are high-quality shape measurements.
10. **Low statistical power** — Per-bandpower theory/σ ≈ 1.3 (theory comparable to Knox error). Expected A_lens S/N ~ 6 per bin with 20 bandpowers. The signal should be detectable.
11. **Observational systematics** — Shear × systematic null tests pass 114/154 (74%) with median χ²/dof = 1.29. The 26% failure rate is elevated above 5% but the chi2 values are moderate (1.6–2.2 for worst per-bin offenders: galactic extinction, star brightness, noise, galaxy density, photo-z quality). This level of systematic contamination cannot explain a 90% signal suppression. By contrast, density × systematic fails 77/77 (expected — galaxy positions correlate with observational depth by construction), yet density × κ gives A_lens = 1.05.

#### Still possible

1. **Missing metacal response correction** — In standard metacal, `e_corrected` is the PSF-corrected ellipticity but NOT divided by the shear response <R>. The response correction is applied at the ensemble level: γ = <e>/<R>. If <R> ~ 0.7 (typical for well-resolved galaxies), this would give A_lens ≈ 0.1/0.7 ≈ 0.15 — still far from 1.0. So this alone doesn't explain the non-detection.

2. **Response correction needed AND response is lower than expected** — If the Euclid metacal response <R> differs from DES/HSC values due to pipeline differences, it could be smaller. But R ~ 0.1 (needed to explain the data) would mean the shapes are nearly unresponsive to shear, inconsistent with the good resolution.

3. **PSF correction consuming the lensing signal** — The SHE validation talks mention persistent PSF size biases. If the PSF model systematically absorbs galaxy shear, the corrected ellipticities would lack lensing correlation. This would be a deep upstream bug.

4. **Unexplained catalog issue** — SHE validation notes "first unblinded cosmological constraints" from RR2, suggesting signal exists for other groups measuring shear 2-point statistics (γγ). If they see signal in γγ but we don't in γ×κ, the issue is subtle.

### Evidence chain

```
density × κ detected (A=1) → CMB κ maps correct + NaMaster works + galaxy positions/n(z) correct
theory verified independently → CCL prediction is right
lensmc == metacal (both ~0.1) → NOT a method-specific bug
map == catalog → NOT a map-making bug
blinding ruled out → cross-correlations unblinded per JC1
calibration m ~ 0.002 → can't explain 90% suppression
shear × systematic mostly passes (74%) → tested systematics don't explain non-detection
density × systematic all fail but density × κ detected → systematic correlations ≠ signal contamination
```

### Next steps

1. **Ask Margherita/Giulio**: Does `e_corrected` need a response correction beyond the m-matrix? What is <R> for this catalog? Has anyone measured γγ auto-spectrum from RR2 and gotten cosmological signal?
2. **Check sp_validation results**: The CosmoStat validation team should have measured γγ from RR2. Do their results show signal?
3. **Estimate <R> from the catalog**: If metacal response can be computed from `she_metacal_r2` and galaxy properties, derive <R> empirically.
fibers.outcome: Resolved: the shear non-detection was caused by incorrect ellipticity sign convention in the NaMaster field construction. Euclid catalogs define position angle from West toward North (not standard IAU North toward East). The correct mapping is pol_conv='EUCLID' → [-e1, +e2] in make_field. With the fix: lensmc×ACT A_lens = 0.880 ± 0.052 (17σ), metacal×ACT = 0.850 ± 0.055 (15σ). Both shear methods detected at high significance with chi2/dof ≈ 0.9-1.0. SPT shear amplitudes are 0.69-0.70, consistent with the known SPT normalization deficit (~15-20% low across all tracers). See shear-sign-convention-test-b751c2ca for the full investigation.

fibers.title: TR1 Analysis Plan for WL/3x2pt
fibers.body:
Source: https://euclid.roe.ac.uk/projects/wl-pipeline/wiki/TR1
Authors: 3x2pt Pipeline Group
Last edit: 31 October 2025

## Summary

TR1 (~30% of DR1 area) defines the analysis setup for DR1. Goal: high standard avoiding systematics impact and confirmation bias. First cosmology papers target simultaneous submission with DR1 public date: **21 October 2026**.

## Blinding Rules

### Catalogue-level tests
- Can be performed anytime
- Maps of shears, positions, auxiliary products (n(z), mixing matrices)

### Data-vector level tests
- **Stage A**: Plot blinded DVs without theory; null tests (B-modes, COSEBIs) allowed
- **Stage B**: Compare blinded DVs to synthetic at reference cosmology; no fitting
- Amendment 20/01/2026: Non-tomographic EE Cl and COSEBI E_n can be plotted/shared

### Inference-level tests
- **Residual tests**: Compute DV shifts from systematics, propagate to S8 shifts — allowed
- **Fixed cosmology**: Needs 3x2pt pipeline group approval
- **Constraining power**: Relative loss (% FoM reduction) from trimming — allowed
- **Full inference**: Do NOT look at Om, S8 posteriors even blinded — needs explicit approval

## Timeline

### Preparatory (by end Oct)
- Define baseline source/lens samples from RR2
- JC-1 provides shift vectors to LE3

### Milestone 1 (start Nov)
- LE3 and KPs ready for validation tests

### Milestone 2 (mid Nov)
- PHZ assigns tomo bin IDs
- SHE computes c-bias, MetaCal responses
- LE3 produces blinded data vectors

### Milestone 3 (end Dec)
- All catalogue-level and null tests performed
- Calibrated n(z) produced
- Baseline scale cuts, model, covariance ready

### Milestone 4 (end Jan)
- Assess systematics impact via residual tests
- Decision: trimmed DV, new sample + iteration, or unblinding

## Cross-SWG Coordination

GC-SWG, TH-SWG, **CMBX-SWG**, and CG-SWG can potentially unblind WL-SWG. JC-1 provides forum for cross-SWG cosmology activities.

## CMBX Implications

- Must coordinate blinding with WL-SWG protocols
- Cross-correlations (κ_CMB × γ, κ_CMB × δ) touch their blinding scheme
- JC-1 is the coordination forum

## Comments
**2026-02-11 03:21** — WL-SWG telecon 2026-02-11: We're past Milestone 3 (end Dec) and into Milestone 4 territory (end Jan). B-modes remain unresolved — tiger team forming (Benjamin). First blinded end-to-end products (power spectra + covariances) available on PEAK. Blinding machinery largely in place; final iteration with JC-1 on shift vectors needed. DPS downtime blocking simulations.

fibers.title: TR1 B-mode investigation
fibers.outcome:
## Status: No smoking gun — tiger team being formed

B-modes are significant in TR1. Bologna meeting (Feb 2026) exhausted all obvious avenues without identifying source. Benjamin to captain a dedicated tiger team.

## What was tried

### Nicholas de Sore — Cl cuts
- Split by faint/bright, large/small objects
- "Interesting things but nothing conclusive"

### 2D mass maps
- Benjamin: "might be a hint of structure" but no smoking gun

### Angus — 2PCF vs CosmoPipe comparison
- Significant B-modes regardless of method (L3 2PCF or KiDS CosmoPipe)
- **Discrepancy between L3 and CosmoPipe on some scales** — being investigated
- Angus provided KiDS data to cross-check; expected to be a fixable issue
- Masking tests: effective coverage mask (>0.8) removes ~couple orders of B-mode but still significant at ~1e-9. Cluster-based mask also doesn't eliminate.

### Chris Duncan — PSF size residuals
- Useful diagnostic but not clearly the source
- PSF looks good on small scales — confusing why B-modes appear on large scales
- PSF has been improved since R2 but large-scale B-modes haven't changed much

### Sasha — rho/tau statistics
- Various patches, faint/bright cuts
- UCL team selected patches avoiding edge/overlap complications
- **PSF appears to be behaving fairly well** — no obvious PSF-galaxy correlation

### Lila — C-bias residual patterns on sky
- Initially noticed funny patterns
- Resolved as projection issue (detector → sky coordinates) with Gordon and Chris
- Redmine issue open for documentation

### Leonor (UCL) — Average ellipticity in clean patches
- Some odd behavior in a few patches
- Not clearly connected to B-modes

### Angus — SOM correlations
- Self-organizing maps looking for ellipticity correlations with survey parameters
- Nothing clear; more detailed analysis planned

## Key discussion points
- **Simulations**: "If only we had simulations" — DPS downtime adds ~1 month delay. Nico clarified: never planned to do 100 sq deg sims, only 32 small patches across DR1. Full survey sims could be prioritized but pipeline is late.
- **PSF propagation**: Would be useful to propagate PSF size biases to see if they produce large-scale B-modes, but no simulation infrastructure for this.
- **Alan**: Offered to run data through ALMANAC (Bayesian B-mode power spectrum sampler) — to coordinate with Benjamin/Sam/Angus.
- **Masking + C-bias recomputation**: Angus plans to recompute C-term after masking selections (now has Jacobians from CosmoHub catalog). Doubts it will change C-term significantly, but wants to test C-term vs brightness etc.

## Assessment
Source unknown. Could be PSF-related, could be something else entirely. "They can hide very well and we have to dig deeper" (Henry). Cannot categorically rule out going "all the way back" to fundamentals.

fibers.title: C-bias FoV diagnostic via pseudo-Cls (Costas)
fibers.outcome:
## Method
Based on Heymans & Schneider (2016) — adapted from real-space correlation functions to pseudo-Cl (flat sky).

**Core idea**: For each tile, compute mean ellipticity in that tile and mean ellipticity of all *other* tiles (complementary stack). Cross-correlating these suppresses cosmic shear signal, isolating C-bias residuals.

- Works in detector-plane coordinates (not HEALPix — flat 100x100 pixel grid per FoV)
- Applies rotation from sky → detector plane, corrects for telescope distortion
- Produces E-mode, B-mode, and EB cross-spectra per FoV
- Multipole range: ~600 (FoV scale) to ~20,000 (0.01 deg within FoV)

## Key results (RR2 data)

### Raw vs C-corrected
- Raw tiles show large C-bias power, especially at FoV scales
- Gordon's C-bias correction significantly reduces power — but **residual power remains**
- Residual power concentrated at ~1-2 points across FoV (larger scales)
- LensMC residuals smaller than MetaCal (MetaCal noisier)

### Statistical significance
- 3-4 sigma detection of residual E and B mode power after C-correction
- Null test (random rotation of ellipticities) → large p-values, consistent with no signal
- EB cross-spectrum consistent with zero

### Method refinement (ongoing)
- **Changed from stacked to single-tile**: Originally stacked ~20 tiles + iterated one at a time. Now uses single tile vs complementary stack — avoids inter-tile correlations, tiles are independent.
- **Bootstrap covariance**: Replaced sub-covariance (scatter across realizations) with bootstrap resampling of fields — measures coherent detector-plane C-bias pattern (survey-average).
- Code speed-ups underway; computationally feasible for TR1/DR1.

## Discussion
- **Wada**: Masking applied per-object (inheriting HEALPix mask values) — didn't change tomography or lens weights.
- **Alex**: C-bias recomputation after masking not yet done (Angus planned).
- **Benjamin**: Advantage over real-space (Heymans & Schneider)? → Complementary, not fundamentally different. Costas has pseudo-Cl experience.
- **Vini**: Can you rotate Cls back to sky coordinates to forward-propagate the systematic? → In principle yes, but limited by FoV scales. Low multipoles unreliable due to large mask.
- **Interpretation**: Primarily a null test / diagnostic tool. Detects residual power but doesn't identify source (could be PSF, electronics, etc.).

## Next steps
- Apply to TR1, then DR1 (standard project for DR1)
- Add tomographic analysis if tile count sufficient
- Link to slides to be shared on WL-SWG common deck
