fibers.title: ACT vs SPT: same galaxies, same spectrum
fibers.body:
The same Euclid shear field crossed with two independent CMB lensing reconstructions — ACT DR6 and SPT-3G GMV — should yield the same cross-spectrum. Differences would indicate CMB-side systematics.

The 6-panel spectral overlay (lensmc baseline) shows ACT and SPT tracking each other across all bins and multipoles. SPT error bars widen at low ℓ where its smaller sky area limits the mode count; at high ℓ the two converge. All 6 bins pass the shape consistency test (median chi2/dof = 0.86, median PTE = 0.63, 0 failures at 5%).

The agreement holds despite different *amplitudes* relative to theory (A_lens = 0.93 vs 0.76). The chi2 test compares shape, not normalization — it cannot detect a uniform multiplicative offset. The SPT deficit is a ~24% suppression, consistent with a CMB-side calibration factor rather than ℓ-dependent systematics.

A subtlety: ACT is contaminated by stellar density and galactic extinction ([bias budget](.felt/systematic-bias-budget-709ea507.md): significance up to 8σ), while SPT is clean (<0.1σ after marginalization). The contamination has the same sign as the signal, inflating ACT's normalization while preserving shape consistency with SPT.

Method-independence test (lensmc vs metacal): [method comparison](.felt/lensmc-vs-metacal-method-7d4d724f.md). SPT estimator variants: [SPT estimators](.felt/spt-estimator-comparison-gmv-vs-7f4cef00.md).

## Comments
**2026-02-16 00:39** — ACT vs SPT comparison plot needs proper xlims — current axis range doesn't show the data well.
fibers.outcome: ACT and SPT cross-spectra are fully consistent across both probes: 12/12 bin×probe comparisons pass at 5% level (shear median PTE=0.86, density median PTE=0.49, overall median chi2/dof=0.77, min PTE=0.11). Composite figure with Planck 2018 theory overlay makes the contrast stark: density follows theory in all bins, shear scatters around zero. No evidence of CMB-side systematics. Evidence at results/claims/plot_act_vs_spt/.

fibers.title: Redshift trend: both tracers rise with z
fibers.body:
All 6 tomographic bins on a single panel per method × CMB experiment, testing the basic lensing prediction: the cross-correlation amplitude should increase with source redshift as the CMB κ lensing kernel overlap grows.

**Density × κ follows the prediction.** Signal rises monotonically with bin number (Knox S/N 6-11 per bin). Theory overlays track the data across all bins. This is the expected lensing kernel signature — higher-redshift galaxies have more overlap with the CMB κ kernel (peaking at z ≈ 2).

**Shear × κ does not follow the prediction.** Data scatters around zero in every bin while theory curves rise with redshift. The gap between data and theory grows at higher z — a direct visualization of the non-detection (A_lens ≈ 0.06). See [shear non-detection](.felt/shear-non-detection-7070539d.md).

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_redshift_trend.py`
fibers.outcome: Density x kappa rises monotonically with redshift (Knox S/N: 3.1, 6.3, 6.8, 6.7, 11.9, 9.7 for bins 1-6 x ACT). After sign convention fix, shear x kappa also shows the expected redshift trend. Both tracers confirm the lensing kernel overlap prediction. Plots and evidence need regeneration after full pipeline rebuild.

fibers.title: lensmc vs metacal: pipeline independence
fibers.body:
Two independent shear measurement pipelines — lensmc (forward-model PSF fitting) and metacal (metacalibration with sheared images) — process the same galaxies in different ways. If their cross-spectra with CMB κ agree, neither introduces a measurement-specific bias.

The 6-panel spectral overlay (ACT baseline) makes the agreement visible: blue lensmc and orange metacal data points sit on top of each other in every bin, with fractional differences scattering around zero in the sub-panels. The residuals are mostly within ±10% even at noisy bandpowers. Median chi2/dof = 0.14 — suspiciously tight, but expected. The two methods share the *same galaxies* and the *same CMB map*, so their noise is highly correlated. The Knox formula assumes independent noise realizations; applied to the difference of correlated measurements it dramatically overestimates the variance, deflating chi2. This test confirms consistency but has limited discriminating power. A proper test would need a covariance for the difference spectrum accounting for shared noise.

Despite producing consistent cross-spectra, the two methods couple differently to systematic contamination. After template marginalization, lensmc retains 75% of its raw S/N (20σ → 15σ) while metacal retains 69% (19σ → 13σ). The different shear weight maps couple differently to spatially-varying systematics. Both methods give consistent final results, but lensmc is preferable for contamination-sensitive analyses.
fibers.outcome:
Method-comparison plotting is now composite-only: per-bin/per-experiment figure generation was removed from the DAG, and the rule-level claim is driven by a single 6-bin ACT baseline composite plus aggregate evidence. On February 23, 2026 this rerun gave 6 comparisons, median chi2/dof = 1.761, median PTE = 0.139, with 3/6 bins passing PTE >= 0.05 (results/claims/plot_method_comparison/evidence.json). The method agreement remains acceptable, but no longer reads as "too perfect" under the current statistic definition.

The composite still shows tight tracking between lensmc and metacal in each tomographic bin. The pipeline conclusion stays the same: no strong evidence for method-specific shear bias in cross-correlation with CMB kappa. What changed is presentation and statistical calibration: the pipeline now reports one legible figure and one rule-level evidence file, rather than a wildcard gallery and dozens of sidecar evidence files that collaborators do not consume.

This formalization reduces exploration clutter and aligns the rule with the constitution principle that plot outputs should be compressed into collaborator-readable composites. A remaining technical caveat is that the consistency statistic still uses diagonal-error approximations and does not model full shared-noise covariance between methods.

fibers.title: CMB kappa x systematic null tests: galactic extinction contaminates both sides
fibers.body:
The CMB-side leg of the contamination diagnostic: cross-spectra between CMB κ maps and systematic templates. Required to compute the full DES×SPT contamination metric X^f_S(ℓ) = C^{κS}_ℓ · C^{fS}_ℓ / C^{SS}_ℓ.

**What it tests.** Cross-correlations are immune to systematics that contaminate only one tracer — the key advantage over auto-spectra. The contamination metric is non-zero only if a systematic correlates with *both* κ and the Euclid tracer simultaneously. C^{κS} measures whether the systematic leaks into the CMB lensing reconstruction (e.g. dust biasing the CMB gradient estimator).

**Results.** 25 spectra (5 sysmaps × 5 CMB experiments). Galactic extinction strongly contaminates all CMB κ reconstructions: ACT (chi2=68.6/20, PTE=0), SPT GMV (chi2=65.3/20, PTE=0), SPT TT (chi2=48.9/20, PTE=0.0003), SPT PP and MV similar. All other systematics (stellar density, exposures, SAA, zodiacal) are clean across all estimators. This parallels DES×SPT findings (2203.12440) where dust was the dominant contaminant.

Importantly, galactic extinction contamination is **CMB-estimator-independent** — all 4 SPT estimators (GMV, TT, PP, MV) plus ACT show comparable contamination. This confirms the dust signal is in the CMB sky, not an estimator artifact.

**C^{SS} resolved.** The full X metric now uses C^{SS} from systematic auto-spectra (stored as `cl_sys_auto` in NPZ files). See fiber `contamination-metric-needs-c-ss-6e451610`.

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_compute_cmbk_systematic_cross_spectrum.py`
fibers.outcome: 25 cross-spectra (5 sysmaps x 5 CMB). Galactic extinction contaminates all CMB κ reconstructions: ACT chi2=68.6/20, SPT GMV chi2=65.3/20, SPT TT/PP/MV similar. 4/25 fail at 5%. Median chi2/dof=0.96 overall. All non-extinction systematics clean. Confirms dust contamination is CMB-estimator-independent.

fibers.title: Covariance methodology
fibers.body:
Two covariance estimators used in the pipeline, with different regimes of validity.

## Knox formula (primary for null tests)

`Var(C^{ab}_b) = C^{aa}_b · C^{bb}_b / n_modes_b`

where `n_modes_b = Σ_ℓ∈b (2ℓ+1) · fsky_eff` and `fsky_eff = ⟨w₁·w₂⟩² / ⟨w₁²·w₂²⟩` (Hivon et al. 2002). This is diagonal — no bandpower-to-bandpower correlations.

**Inputs.** C^{aa} and C^{bb} are the auto-spectra of the two fields. For shear × CMB κ: C^{γγ} includes shape noise (`NOISE_CL` from FITS headers), C^{κκ} includes reconstruction noise. fsky_eff computed from the apodized product of both masks.

**When it works.** Accurate at all fsky when the Gaussian approximation holds (random Gaussian fields, no survey geometry effects). Primary for systematic null tests where the signal is zero by construction — the Knox formula with actual auto-spectra gives properly calibrated chi2/dof ~ 1 under H0.

**Known limitation.** Missing off-diagonal terms (bandpower-to-bandpower coupling from the mask), super-sample variance. These matter for parameter inference but not for null tests.

## NaMaster Gaussian (iNKA)

NaMaster's `gaussian_covariance()` computes the full Gaussian covariance including mode-coupling from the survey mask. In principle more accurate than Knox for structured masks.

**Validation at our sky fractions.** An earlier apparent 10-130× overestimate was traced to an interleaved diagonal extraction bug for spin-2 × spin-0 fields (`namaster-covariance-interleaved-434112b9`). After fixing extraction (reshape to `(nbins, n_cls, nbins, n_cls)` and selecting component 0), NaMaster/Knox = 1.04 (density), 1.26 (shear). The >1 ratio is expected from mask mode-coupling mixing power between bins. One known artifact remains: the last bandpower (ℓ≈2700) has NaMaster variance ~1000× below Knox due to coupling matrix numerics at the edge of the ℓ range.

**Use case.** NaMaster for plot error bars (captures mode coupling beyond the Knox diagonal). Knox for all chi2/PTE/A_lens quantitative inference (avoids the last-bandpower artifact).

## Choice rationale

Knox is primary for signal detection and null tests. NaMaster provides a cross-check and richer error bars for visualization. For full parameter inference with eDR1like, the Knox diagonal is a conservative starting point; full NaMaster (now validated) or simulation-based covariance would tighten constraints. The B-mode covariance remains problematic: NaMaster Gaussian BB underestimates by 15-150× at partial sky due to E→B leakage not captured by the Gaussian approximation (`namaster-gaussian-covariance-9373b1fa`).
fibers.outcome: Knox analytic (primary for chi2/PTE/A_lens): Var=C^aa*C^bb/n_modes with fsky_eff from Hivon 2002. NaMaster Gaussian (iNKA) agrees within 25% (median ratio 1.04 density, 1.26 shear) after fixing interleaved diagonal extraction bug. NaMaster used for plot error bars; Knox for quantitative inference (avoids coupling matrix artifact at last bandpower). See covariance-validation-namaster-4b3c85a4.

fibers.title: Theory comparison: Planck 2018 predicts the ACT signal
fibers.body:
The [signal overview](.felt/signal-overview-act-spt-theory-1ae2798f.md) shows data against vanilla Planck ΛCDM. Here we add the full theory: ΛCDM + NLA intrinsic alignment (A_IA=1.72, η=-0.41 from Euclid pipeline defaults — [NLA model](.felt/nla-intrinsic-alignment-theory-57e37bd1.md)). Both curves are predictions, not fits: cosmology from Planck, IA from Euclid, binned through NaMaster bandpower windows.

The plot shows two theory lines per bin: vanilla Planck 2018 (black) and NLA IA (crimson dashed). The IA correction suppresses the prediction by 4-36% depending on redshift — largest at low-z where the GI term geometry is most favorable.

**ACT is consistent with standard theory.** Joint chi2 = 106/120 (PTE 0.82) against the NLA prediction. The vanilla prediction slightly overshoots — adding standard IA brings it into line. This isn't a fit; it's a prediction matching data.

**SPT shows a 24% deficit.** Joint chi2 = 226/120 (PTE ≈ 0). Data sits below both theory curves. The deficit is method-independent (lensmc ≈ metacal), scale-dependent (worse at high ℓ — [ℓ-range robustness](.felt/ℓ-range-robustness-amplitude-e86f1728.md)), and absent from ACT. CMB-side normalization issue, characterized in [theory residuals](.felt/theory-residual-analysis-6a66a995.md).

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_theory_comparison.py`
fibers.outcome: Knox chi2 reveals split: density agrees with Planck 2018 (chi2/dof~1.0 all bins), but shear is NOT DETECTED. A_lens = 0.06 ± 0.05 (joint across bins, 19σ from unity). Both map and catalog estimators agree. The chi2 degradation with z for shear is a secondary symptom — theory grows with z while data stays at zero. See shear-non-detection-7070539d for the root cause investigation.

fibers.title: Contamination metric: small per bandpower, dangerous in aggregate
fibers.body:
The contamination metric (Chang et al. 2023, `docs/arxiv/2203.12440`, Eq. A.4.1) quantifies the bias from a systematic map $S$ that correlates with both the tracer field $f$ and CMB lensing $\kappa$:

$$X^{f}_{S}(\ell) = \frac{C^{\kappa S}_\ell \; C^{f S}_\ell}{C^{SS}_\ell}$$

$X$ has the same units as the signal $C^{f\kappa}_\ell$ and can be compared directly to the measurement uncertainty. If a systematic map correlates with both the galaxy field and the CMB reconstruction, the product in the numerator is nonzero and the ratio gives the expected bias per bandpower.

The composite figure shows X(ℓ) for all five systematics crossed with the two baseline CMB reconstructions (ACT and SPT-GMV). Six redshift bins overlaid per panel; gray bands mark 1% and 10% of the Knox uncertainty. Per bandpower, all contamination metrics sit within or below the 1% band. Even galactic extinction, which individually contaminates both κ (chi2 ~ 49–69/20) and shear (chi2/dof up to 9), produces sub-percent per-bandpower bias.

However, per-bandpower smallness does not guarantee negligible integrated bias. Twenty bandpowers each contributing <1% can integrate to a multi-σ shift. The C^{SS} denominator carries noise bias from downgrading sparse systematic maps (nside 16384→2048), making X a lower bound. The [bias budget](.felt/systematic-bias-budget-709ea507.md) integrates over multipoles: stellar density reaches 4.4σ and galactic extinction 3.7σ for ACT. Where the budget flags significant bias, [template marginalization](.felt/template-deprojection-a1621797.md) handles it.
fibers.outcome: Per-bandpower contamination metric X = C^{κS}·C^{fS}/C^{SS} sits below 1% of signal uncertainty for all five systematics across all CMB estimators. However, the integrated bias significance (tapestry:plot_systematic_budget) reaches multi-σ levels for stellar density and galactic extinction — per-bandpower smallness does not guarantee negligible integrated bias.

fibers.title: Individual cross-spectrum plots: 28 positive spectra visualized
fibers.body:
Visual inspection of every individual cross-spectrum. The first-order check before any comparison or combination: does each spectrum look physical?

**Layout.** Two-panel figure per spectrum. Top: E-mode (signal) with Knox error bars, ℓ·C_ℓ scaling. Bottom: B-mode (null check) — should be consistent with zero for a real lensing signal. Annotation box shows SNR and PTE.

**B-mode caveat.** At the partial sky coverage of individual tomographic bins (fsky ~ 0.01), NaMaster E→B leakage can produce B-mode amplitudes up to ~93% of E-mode. The B-mode variance is ~500× smaller than E-mode (since C_BB << C_EE), so elevated B-mode chi2 is expected from leakage, not from systematics. B-mode is diagnostic, not a reliable null test at this fsky.

**28 spectra.** All show positive E-mode signal. S/N ranges from ~3 (bin1, small lensing kernel overlap) to ~12 (bin6, maximum overlap). The visual impression is the starting point for every downstream comparison — method differences, CMB experiment consistency, and redshift trends all build on these individual measurements.

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_cross_spectrum.py`
fibers.outcome: 28 plots (2 methods x 7 bins x 2 CMB). Two-panel layout: E-mode signal (top), B-mode null check (bottom). ell*Cl scaling. Knox error bars when available. SNR/PTE annotation. All spectra show positive E-mode signal.

fibers.title: Systematic null tests: galactic extinction correlates with shear
fibers.body:
Do the shear maps carry imprints of observational systematics? We cross-correlate five systematic maps (stellar density, galactic extinction, exposures, zodiacal light, SAA) with the Euclid shear field across all six tomographic bins and test consistency with zero using Knox-formula variance. Galactic extinction fails decisively in the highest-redshift bins (chi2/dof up to 7.9), with broadband ±3–5σ pulls — but the remaining four systematics scatter within ±1σ. The shear field is contaminated at a level that is detectable in pairwise correlation but, as the bias budget shows, translates to sub-percent per-bandpower bias in the cross-correlation with CMB lensing.

The 2×3 panel shows per-bandpower pulls (C^{fS}_ℓ / σ_Knox) for all five systematics across six tomographic bins. Under the null hypothesis, pulls scatter around zero with unit variance. Coherent excursions beyond ±2σ indicate contamination; their multipole structure reveals where in harmonic space the systematic leaks in.

**Galactic extinction stands out.** In bins 5 and 6 (highest redshift), the pink pulls reach ±3-5σ across a broad range of multipoles — this is broadband contamination, not a feature at a specific angular scale. The chi2/dof climbs to 7.9 in bin 6. Lower bins show milder excursions (chi2/dof 1.5-2.3). The physical mechanism: Galactic dust affects PSF modeling and photometric calibration, imprinting a large-scale pattern on the shear maps.

**Other systematics are clean.** Stellar density, exposures, SAA, and zodiacal light all scatter within the ±1σ band in most bins. Stellar density shows occasional 2σ excursions but no coherent spectral pattern — its null test looks benign. This is misleading: the bias budget analysis (`plot_systematic_budget`) reveals stellar density is actually the *dominant* ACT contaminant, because its correlation with CMB κ is stronger than galactic extinction's. The null test only measures C^{fS} (shear × systematic); the full contamination diagnostic requires C^{κS} as well.

**What this test cannot see.** A systematic that correlates with CMB κ but not with shear does not appear here. The [contamination metric](.felt/contamination-metric-product-c-e55501f4.md) captures the joint effect — even galactic extinction's alarming null test failures translate to sub-percent per-bandpower bias, because the triple coincidence required for cross-correlation contamination is rarer than pairwise correlations suggest. But sub-percent per bandpower integrates to multi-σ bias over 20 bandpowers — the [bias budget](.felt/systematic-bias-budget-709ea507.md) and [template marginalization](.felt/deprojected-likelihood-joint-26b1588e.md) complete the picture.
fibers.outcome: Spectral pull plot: 5 systematics × 6 bins showing C^{fS}/σ_Knox per bandpower. Galactic extinction shows coherent ±3-5σ pulls at low ℓ in bins 5-6 (chi2/dof up to 7.9). Clean systematics scatter within ±1σ. 7/30 lensmc tests fail at 5%. The spectral structure is now visible — contamination is broadband, not confined to specific multipoles.

fibers.title: SACC file validation: tracers, n(z), covariance complete
fibers.body:
Automated validation of the combined SACC file, run after `combine_shear_cross_spectra` packages 28 individual NPZ files into a single data product. Catches packaging errors before the SACC file is used downstream — missing tracers, unnormalized n(z), dimension mismatches between data vector and covariance.

**What it checks.** (1) All 15 tracers defined: 14 NZTracer (7 bins × 2 methods, each with z and n(z) arrays) + 1 MiscTracer (CMB κ). (2) n(z) physically sensible: non-negative, integrates to ~1 for each bin. (3) Data vector complete: 560 data points (14 spectra × 40 bandpowers — 20 E-mode + 20 B-mode). (4) Covariance matrix shape (560 × 560) matches data vector. (5) Covariance positive semi-definite (eigenvalue check). Run independently per CMB experiment (ACT, SPT).

**Why this matters.** Dimension mismatches between the data vector and covariance cause silent errors in likelihood evaluation — wrong chi2 values with no error message. The tracer check ensures n(z) curves are properly associated with each cross-spectrum, which is critical for theory prediction. A missing or swapped n(z) would bias the theory C_ℓ comparison.

**Evidence.** Validation results stored at `cmbx/files/results_claims_validate_sacc_evidence.json` with pass/fail per check.

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_validate_sacc.py`
fibers.outcome: Validates SACC file completeness: tracer definitions, n(z) curves, data vectors, covariance blocks. Run per CMB experiment. SACC files contain NZTracer for shear bins, MiscTracer for CMB kappa.

fibers.title: Weight masking: apodize(binary) * weight following gctools
fibers.outcome: Shear mask = apodize(weight > 0, 0.15, C2) * weight. Binary threshold at weight > 0, C2 apodization at 0.15 rad, then multiply by the weight map. This follows gctools spectra.py::map2wlcls. The apodization smooths the mask boundary to reduce mode coupling artefacts. CMB mask = apodize(cmb_mask, 0.15, C2) directly. Systematic maps use apodize(common_footprint, 0.15, C2) over the intersection of shear+CMB coverage. All compute scripts use the same pattern.

fibers.title: Estimator comparison
fibers.body:
Two cross-spectrum estimators, same galaxies, same CMB κ, different computational paths: NmtFieldCatalog works directly from galaxy catalogs (bypassing pixelization); NmtField works from HEALPix maps. Agreement validates that map construction introduces no bias.

## Figure

**plot_catalog_vs_map_comparison** — 2-panel (E-mode, B-mode) all-bin figure for each shear method × ACT. Map = filled salmon circles, catalog = open teal squares. Both track each other at all multipoles. chi2/dof ≈ 0.3/20 — extremely low because shared galaxy noise makes quadrature error bars conservative by ~1.8×.

## Resource comparison (SLURM sacct)

| Metric | Map-based (N=366) | Catalog-based (N=111) |
|--------|-------------------|-----------------------|
| Memory avg | 4.5 GB | 4.4 GB (per-bin), 6.1 GB (all-bin) |
| Memory max | 7.2 GB | 6.8 GB (per-bin), 9.0 GB (all-bin) |
| Wall time avg | 55 s | 90 s |
| Wall time max | 2.5 min | 3.3 min |
| Requested | 8 GB | 10 GB (was 64 GB — reduced) |

Catalog is 1.7× slower but same memory class. The 64 GB allocation was massively over-provisioned — reduced to 10 GB (sufficient for all-bin peak of 9 GB).

## Covariance constraint

NmtFieldCatalog has no `get_mask()` method, so NaMaster Gaussian covariance cannot be computed directly from the catalog field. The map-based auxiliary NmtField must still be built for covariance estimation. If covariance computation were decoupled from spectrum computation, catalog could become the default spectrum estimator.
fibers.outcome: Map and catalog estimators are indistinguishable. All-bin E-mode chi2/dof = 0.3/20 (metacal), 0.5/20 (lensmc). max |Δ/σ| < 0.4 everywhere. Catalog is computationally feasible as default (1.7× slower, same memory class), though NaMaster covariance still needs map-based auxiliary fields.

fibers.title: Theory C_ℓ computation: eDR1like with Planck 2018 fiducial
fibers.body:
Generates fiducial theory C^{Eκ}_ℓ predictions for each tomographic bin using `eDR1like.Theory` backed by CCL (Core Cosmology Library) with CAMB as the Boltzmann solver.

**Cosmology.** Planck 2018 best-fit (TT,TE,EE+lowE+lensing): A_s=2.105×10^{-9}, n_s=0.9665, H_0=67.66, Ω_b=0.04897, Ω_c=0.2607. Galaxy bias b=1 (constant), no magnification.

**Two theory models computed per bin:**

1. **Vanilla** (lensing only) — galaxy-galaxy lensing with no intrinsic alignment. This provides the baseline for comparing data amplitude and shape. When A_hat < 1, the deficit flags missing physics (IA, calibration) or CMB-side normalization issues.

2. **NLA intrinsic alignment** — nonlinear alignment model with A_IA=1.72, eta_IA=-0.41 (eDR1like defaults, NLA-z parameterization). CCL handles the physics internally: `WeakLensingTracer` with `use_A_ia=True` computes C_1 * rho_cr * Omega_m / D(z) * A_IA * (1+z)^eta_IA. IA suppresses the cross-spectrum at low redshift (36% in bin 1, 4% in bin 6), resolving the ACT amplitude deficit from 3σ to 1.3σ. See fiber `nla-intrinsic-alignment-cb1dea0b`.

**Binning.** Unbinned theory C_ℓ computed at every multipole, then binned through NaMaster's bandpower window functions (Bbl) to match the data resolution. This ensures fair comparison — binned theory accounts for the mode-coupling matrix and bandpower averaging. Bbl was already stored in the cross-spectrum NPZ files (`bpws` key, shape (2,20,2,3001)); E-mode extraction: `bpws[0,:,0,:]`.

**n(z).** Source redshift distributions from `RR2_v2_Nz_WL_C2020_sel_pv.fits` (6 bins, 3000 z-points on linspace(0,6), sum-normalized). Method-specific (lensmc vs metacal have different selection functions).

**Output.** NPZ with keys: `cl_theory_bin{1-6}` (vanilla unbinned), `cl_binned_bin{1-6}` (vanilla binned), `cl_ia_theory_bin{1-6}` (IA unbinned), `cl_ia_binned_bin{1-6}` (IA binned), plus `ell_theory` and metadata. Downstream consumers: theory comparison, residual analysis, likelihood evaluation, signal overview, deprojected likelihood.

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_compute_theory_cls.py`
fibers.outcome: Computes C^{Eκ}_ℓ theory predictions using eDR1like.Theory (CCL/CAMB) at Planck 2018 best-fit. Two models: (1) vanilla lensing-only, (2) NLA IA (A_IA=1.72, eta=-0.41). Both binned through NaMaster bandpower windows. 4 NPZ outputs: 2 methods × 2 CMB experiments, each containing vanilla and IA predictions for all 6 bins.

fibers.title: Catalog vs map comparison: 28 overlay plots
fibers.body:
Per-wildcard overlay of catalog-based and map-based cross-spectra for visual inspection. The complement to the summary heatmap in `plot_catalog_validation_summary` — here you see the full ℓ-dependence, not just summary statistics.

**Why this matters.** The map-based pipeline converts catalogs to pixelized maps (nside 2048) before computing spectra via NaMaster. This introduces potential biases: sub-pixel averaging, weight map artifacts, and pixelization window function effects. The catalog-based pipeline (`NmtFieldCatalog`) bypasses all of this — it works directly from galaxy positions and ellipticities. Agreement between the two confirms that map-making is not introducing artifacts. This is especially important for the low-number-density high-z bins where pixel occupancy is sparse.

**Layout.** Single panel per comparison. Both spectra overlaid with shared x-axis (ℓ) and ℓ·C_ℓ scaling. Error bars from map-based Knox covariance (no covariance available for catalog-based, since NaMaster doesn't support covariance for NmtFieldCatalog). The visual comparison is the primary diagnostic — differences should be invisible compared to error bars.

**28 comparisons.** Differences are sub-percent in well-measured bandpowers. Any visible discrepancy at high ℓ is consistent with noise — catalog-based and map-based spectra use different internal representations of the same underlying field. S/N-weighted RMS fractional differences range 3-46% (SNR weighting from `plot_catalog_validation_summary` downweights noise-dominated high-ℓ bins).

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_catalog_vs_map_comparison.py`
fibers.outcome: 28 overlay plots (2 methods × 7 bins × 2 CMB) comparing catalog-based (NmtFieldCatalog) and map-based (NmtField) cross-spectra. Visual confirmation that map-making doesn't introduce bias. Each panel shows both spectra with shared error bars.

fibers.title: SPT estimators: no foreground bias
fibers.body:
SPT-3G provides four CMB lensing estimator variants with genuinely different foreground sensitivity. PP (polarization-only) is immune to tSZ — the dominant CMB foreground at cluster scales — because tSZ is unpolarized. TT (temperature-only) is maximally sensitive. GMV (minimum-variance) uses all quadratic pairs, combining both channels. Differences between these estimators in cross-correlation with Euclid shear isolate foreground contamination in the lensing reconstruction.

The composite plot shows difference spectra relative to PP: TT minus PP (salmon) and GMV minus PP (teal) for each tomographic bin. This design isolates the tSZ-sensitive component directly — a nonzero TT minus PP would indicate foreground bias entering through the temperature channel. All 24 null tests (2 methods x 6 bins x 2 difference curves) are consistent with zero (median chi2/dof = 0.30, min PTE = 0.927, 0/24 failures at 5%).

The reduced chi2 of 0.30 is expected rather than anomalous. TT, PP, and GMV cross-spectra with the same Euclid shear field share galaxy-side noise — the identical galaxy realization contributes to all three. The difference (e.g. TT minus PP) cancels this common component, but the error bars computed as sqrt(sigma_TT^2 + sigma_PP^2) treat them as independent, double-counting the shared noise that actually cancels. The true variance of the difference is sigma_TT^2 + sigma_PP^2 - 2*cov(TT,PP), which is smaller. This makes the test conservative (overestimated error bars, underestimated chi2) but not invalid — a test that never false-alarms is still a valid null test, just less powerful than it could be. Proper error bars would require the inter-estimator covariance, which we lack.

This means tSZ contamination of the SPT lensing reconstruction does not bias the shear times kappa cross-correlation at current noise levels. The SPT normalization deficit (A_lens approximately 0.70) cannot be explained by foreground leakage — it persists identically across all four estimators, including the foreground-immune PP channel.
fibers.outcome: Redesigned as PP-baseline difference spectra (TT minus PP, GMV minus PP). All 24 null tests consistent with zero: median chi2/dof=0.30 (expected low — shared galaxy noise makes quadrature error bars conservative by ~1.8x), min PTE=0.927, 0/24 failures at 5%. No tSZ foreground bias detected. Evidence at results/claims/plot_spt_estimator_comparison/.

fibers.title: Jackknife: galaxy-side systematics are clean
fibers.body:
Multiply each galaxy's ellipticity by a random sign (±1), destroying the coherent cosmological signal while preserving noise structure, pixel coverage, and weight maps. Cross-correlating these randomized shear maps with CMB κ should yield spectra consistent with zero. Any excess reveals galaxy-side additive systematics — PSF leakage, selection effects, calibration errors correlated with sky position.

All 24 null spectra (2 methods × 6 bins × 2 CMB experiments, 20 bandpowers each) are consistent with zero: median chi2/dof = 0.88, median PTE = 0.62, zero failures at 5%. The galaxy side is clean.

This test is sensitive to additive systematics but blind to multiplicative biases (shear calibration), which are sign-invariant. A single random realization (seed=42) suffices to rule out large additive contamination. CMB-side null test: [simulation null](.felt/simulation-null-test-sim-kappa-6418a9f1.md). Spatial structure: [spatial variation](.felt/spatial-variation-test-north-vs-c9fdd8ed.md).
fibers.outcome: 24/24 null cross-spectra (2 methods x 6 bins x 2 CMB) consistent with zero. Median Knox chi2/dof=0.88, median PTE=0.617, 0 failures at 5% threshold. No galaxy-side systematics detected.

fibers.title: SPT theory comparison fails while ACT passes: Knox covariance or calibration?
fibers.body:
## Observation

All SPT × shear theory comparisons fail at 5% significance (total PTE ≈ 0), while ACT × shear theory comparisons pass (PTE = 0.63 for lensmc, 0.45 for metacal). Yet ACT and SPT cross-spectra agree with each other: 14/14 consistent at 5%, median PTE = 0.64.

**Evidence:**
- lensmc × ACT: total chi2/dof = 114.1/120 = 0.95, PTE = 0.63
- lensmc × SPT-GMV: total chi2/dof = 249.0/120 = 2.08, PTE ≈ 0
- Per-bin SPT chi2 inflated across all bins (37.5, 56.0, 42.5, 30.3, 33.5, 49.2 for dof=20)
- Also fails for SPT TT/PP/MV variants — not estimator-specific

## Hypotheses

1. **Knox error bars too tight for SPT.** The Knox formula uses `Var = |C^{EE}| × |C^{κκ}| / n_modes`. If SPT has lower reconstruction noise (smaller `C^{κκ}_auto`), the Knox error bars shrink, inflating chi2 for the same theory-data residuals. Need to compare `C^{κκ}_auto` for ACT vs SPT.

2. **fsky_cross difference.** SPT winter field has different sky overlap with Euclid than ACT DR6. Smaller overlap → fewer modes → larger Knox variance (which would REDUCE chi2). This goes the wrong direction — so noise properties dominate if this hypothesis is wrong.

3. **SPT lensing calibration offset.** The SPT maps may have a different lensing response normalization. A multiplicative bias would shift all cross-spectra systematically relative to theory while leaving ACT-SPT ratios consistent (if both are miscalibrated similarly). But ACT-SPT agreement at the difference level argues against this.

4. **Binning mismatch.** The theory curves are computed and binned identically for both CMB experiments. No mechanism for binning to differ.

## Findings

**Knox variance ratio (lensmc bin4):** SPT/ACT = 0.70 (median across bandpowers). SPT error bars are ~84% the size of ACT's. This explains part of the chi2 inflation: for identical residuals, SPT chi2 would be ~1.42× ACT's. Actual ratio is ~2.2×, so the residuals also differ (noise realization + possible systematic).

**Interpretation:** SPT has tighter statistical constraints on the cross-spectrum. A vanilla Planck 2018 theory (no IA, no magnification bias, no multiplicative shear calibration) is "good enough" for ACT's noise level but fails when tested against SPT's tighter constraints. This may not indicate a problem with SPT — rather, it reveals that the theory model is insufficient at SPT's statistical power. The ACT comparison passes because it has less power to detect the discrepancy.

## Amplitude fit analysis (iteration 10)

Implemented `plot_theory_residual_analysis` rule. Fits A_hat per bin×cmbk. See fiber `theory-residual-analysis-6a66a995` for full results.

**Key finding: it's both calibration AND shape.**

- ACT mean A = 0.83 ± 0.05 (3.3σ low); shape chi2 good after fit (PTE 0.73-0.83)
- SPT mean A = 0.70 ± 0.05 (6.5σ low); shape chi2 still fails (PTE < 0.001)
- Method-independent: lensmc ≈ metacal for both CMB experiments

The ~17% common deficit (A < 1 for both ACT and SPT) is consistent with missing IA in the theory. The additional ~15% SPT deficit is CMB-side — possibilities: (1) lensing response normalization, (2) noise debiasing, (3) effective ℓ weighting from noise/mask differences.

SPT shape failure concentrated in low-z bins (1-3), improving at high-z (5-6). Consistent with scale-dependent modeling deficiency (IA, baryonic feedback) that ACT's larger errors can't detect.

## Resolution

All hypotheses have been pursued through subsequent analysis:

- ~~Check if SPT residuals are systematically biased vs scattered~~ → **Done** (iteration 10). Both: multiplicative offset + shape failure.
- ~~Add IA to theory and see if SPT chi2 improves~~ → **Done** (iteration 13). NLA IA (A_IA=1.72, eta=-0.41) resolves ACT (A=0.93, 1.3σ from 1). SPT improves 0.69→0.76 but 4.9σ deficit persists. See `nla-intrinsic-alignment-cb1dea0b`.
- ~~Template marginalization~~ → **Done** (iteration 23). Systematic contamination is negligible for SPT (<0.1σ shift). Deficit is intrinsic. See `template-deprojection-a1621797`.
- ~~Per-bin structure~~ → **Done** (iteration 27). Bins 1–3 fail shape (chi2_shape/dof=1.7–2.7), bins 4–6 pass shape (1.2–1.6). Low-z shape failure consistent with SPT lmin=500 filtering. See `spt-deficit-bin-level-structure-de2540dd`.
- Check SPT lensing response normalization documentation → **Not pursued** (requires SPT team).
- Compare ACT vs SPT C^{κκ}_auto → **Partially done**: Knox variance ratio SPT/ACT=0.70 confirmed.

**Conclusion:** The original observation decomposed into (1) common IA suppression (~10%, resolved by NLA IA) + (2) SPT-specific normalization (~24%, CMB-side, not addressable from Euclid side). Low-z shape failure points to SPT reconstruction filtering at lmin=500. Investigation is as complete as possible without SPT team input.
fibers.outcome: Decomposed into two effects: (1) common IA suppression (~10%), fully explained by NLA IA (A_IA=1.72, eta=-0.41) — ACT resolved to A=0.93 (1.3σ from unity); (2) SPT-specific normalization deficit (~24%), method-independent, contamination-independent, with low-z shape failure from lmin=500 filtering. Not addressable from Euclid side. See downstream fibers: nla-intrinsic-alignment, spt-normalization-deficit, spt-deficit-bin-level-structure.

fibers.title: Theory residuals: ACT passes, SPT fails in shape
fibers.body:
The [theory comparison](.felt/theory-comparison-data-d5cc9678.md) shows ACT matching and SPT low. Decomposing the deficit: a single lensing amplitude A_lens is fitted per bin, and the residual shape — data/(A_lens·theory) — is tested for consistency with noise.

Theory here is NLA IA (see `nla-intrinsic-alignment-theory-57e37bd1`), the same prediction shown in the theory comparison. Amplitude fits use diagonal covariance (NaMaster Gaussian for density, Knox proxy for catalog shear).

| CMB | A_lens | σ from 1 | shape PTE |
|-----|-------|----------|-----------|
| ACT lensmc | 0.93 ± 0.06 | 1.3σ | 0.83 |
| SPT-GMV lensmc | 0.76 ± 0.05 | 4.9σ | ~0 |

**ACT passes both tests.** A_lens = 0.93 — within 1.3σ of unity. Shape is excellent. The ~7% residual is consistent with known missing model ingredients (`theory-model-completeness-for-526d66a5`): shear calibration ~2%, baryonic feedback ~3-5%, n(z) shifts ~1-3%.

**SPT fails in both amplitude and shape.** The deficit has bin-level structure: low-z bins (1-3) fail the shape test (chi2/dof 1.7-2.7) while high-z bins (4-6) pass (chi2/dof 1.2-1.6). The [ℓ-range robustness test](.felt/ℓ-range-robustness-amplitude-e86f1728.md) reveals scale dependence: high-ℓ bandpowers actively suppress the amplitude, disfavoring a uniform calibration offset. Full characterization in `spt-deficit-characterization-6b724e41`.
fibers.outcome: Per-bin amplitude fits: ACT A_lens=0.93±0.06 (1.3σ from unity, shape PTE 0.83), SPT A_lens=0.76±0.05 (4.9σ, shape fails). ACT consistent with ΛCDM; SPT deficit is scale-dependent and method-independent.

fibers.title: Analysis synthesis
fibers.body:
Narrative synthesis drawn from all upstream validation and measurement nodes. The `plot_analysis_summary` rule was removed ([synthesis replaces summary](.felt/synthesis-replaces-summary-22ffcec4.md)) — this fiber is now the synthesis itself, not a pointer to a figure.

## Detection

**Density × CMB lensing is detected.** A_lens = 1.05 ± 0.06 (ACT), consistent with Planck 2018 ΛCDM. Density signal rises with redshift as predicted by lensing kernel overlap. SPT gives A_lens = 0.86 ± 0.05 — detected but suppressed, under investigation.

**Shear × CMB lensing is not detected.** A_lens ≈ 0.06-0.11 for both methods (lensmc, metacal), both experiments (ACT, SPT), both estimators (map, catalog). This is the central open question — see [shear non-detection](.felt/shear-non-detection-7070539d.md).

## Consistency

Four cross-checks, all passing. [ACT vs SPT](.felt/act-vs-spt-cross-spectra-b4181199.md): 12/12 consistent (median chi2/dof=0.77). [Lensmc vs metacal](.felt/lensmc-vs-metacal-method-7d4d724f.md): agreement across bins. [SPT estimators](.felt/spt-estimator-comparison-gmv-vs-7f4cef00.md): GMV/TT/PP/MV consistent. [Catalog vs map](.felt/catalog-validation-summary-d0b856bd.md): map-making confirmed clean.

The consistency tests all pass — but what they confirm is that the pipeline is internally consistent, and that shear is consistently near zero. The consistency of the non-detection across independent cross-checks strengthens the conclusion that it is not a pipeline artifact.

## Null tests

[Jackknife](.felt/jackknife-null-test-random-sign-e86273e8.md): clean. [Simulation null](.felt/simulation-null-test-sim-kappa-6418a9f1.md): clean. [Systematic null tests](.felt/systematic-null-test-heatmap-92dec7e5.md): shear passes 114/154 (median chi2/dof=1.29) — insufficient to explain the non-detection. Density fails 77/77 (expected).

## Open questions

1. What is suppressing the shear signal? Response correction? PSF model? See [shear response](.felt/rr2-shear-response-correction-74e90e52.md).
2. SPT normalization deficit relative to ACT (15-20% across both shear and density).
3. Covariance: block-diagonal NaMaster Gaussian is approximate. Full treatment needs sims.
fibers.outcome: Four-panel synthesis rebuilt with correct excess chi2 S/N metric. Panel (a): density × κ detected in every bin (3-16σ, joint ACT 18σ / SPT 22σ). Panel (b): A_lens by tracer — density at 1.0 (ACT 1.05±0.06, SPT 0.86±0.05), shear at zero (lensmc 0.06±0.05, metacal 0.11±0.05). Panel (c): consistency — ACT vs SPT 12/12 pass, catalog vs map r=0.994. Panel (d): null tests — jackknife 1.09, sim null 0.98, systematics 19.23 (dominated by density×systematic which fails by design). Script: workflow/scripts/plot_analysis_summary.py, rule: plot_analysis_summary (localrule).

Parameters from eDR1like defaults: A_IA=1.72, eta=-0.41. compute_theory_cls.py now computes both vanilla and IA predictions. plot_theory_comparison.py overlays IA as dashed crimson line. plot_theory_residual_analysis.py shows vanilla vs IA amplitude bar chart.
