fibers.title: Introduction
fibers.body:
Cross-correlating CMB lensing convergence with the shapes and positions of photometric galaxies probes the growth of large-scale structure across cosmic time, testing ΛCDM with independent observables from two entirely different physical effects. This analysis measures C_ℓ^{γκ} and C_ℓ^{δκ} between Euclid RR2 weak lensing shear / galaxy density and CMB lensing convergence from ACT DR6 and SPT-3G (winter), across 6 tomographic bins.

**Headline result**: Both cross-correlations are detected at high significance with ACT DR6 after resolving the Euclid position-angle sign convention (`pol_conv="EUCLID"` → [-e1, +e2] for NaMaster; see `shear-sign-convention-test-b751c2ca`). Galaxy density × CMB-κ: A_lens = 1.049 ± 0.063 (ACT, χ²/dof = 1.07), 0.857 ± 0.050 (SPT). Shear × CMB-κ: A_lens = 0.880 ± 0.052 (lensmc × ACT, 17σ), 0.850 ± 0.055 (metacal × ACT, 15σ), 0.694 ± 0.045 (lensmc × SPT), 0.697 ± 0.048 (metacal × SPT). After marginalizing over 11 systematic contamination templates: density A_lens = 0.986 ± 0.122 (ACT), 0.812 ± 0.122 (SPT); shear A_lens = 0.824 ± 0.095 (lensmc × ACT), 0.780 ± 0.097 (metacal × ACT). SPT shows a persistent 15–20% amplitude deficit across all tracers — a CMB-side normalization issue under investigation (`spt-deficit-characterization-6b724e41`).

**Motivation**: CMB lensing × cosmic shear is insensitive to additive shear systematics (which don't correlate with the CMB) and CMB lensing multiplicative biases — making it a robust, nearly model-independent probe of the projected matter distribution at z ~ 0.3–1.5. Euclid's wide southern survey provides the galaxy data; ACT and SPT provide CMB lensing over overlapping patches of 261 deg² and 115 deg² respectively.

**Comparator analyses**: 
- DES × ACT DR6: Qu+ 2023 (`docs/papers/2309.04412_act_des_shear/main.tex`).
- DES × SPT methods: Chang+ 2022 (`docs/papers/2203.12439_des_spt_planck_methods/main.tex`).
- DES × SPT correlations: Omori+ 2022 (`docs/papers/2203.12440_des_spt_planck_correlations/main.tex`).
- DES × SPT 2026 update: `cmbx/files/docs_papers_des_spt_shearxlensing_2026_shearXlensing_20260202.pdf`.
- ACT DR6 lensing power spectrum: Madhavacheril+ 2024 (`cmbx/files/docs_arxiv_2304.05202_act_dr6_lensing_power_main.tex`).
- SPT-3G winter lensing: `cmbx/files/docs_papers_spt_winter_lensing_apssamp.tex`.

**Collaboration**: SPT-Euclid MoU (DR1-KP-CMBX-3/2) — see [MOU proposal](.felt/spt-euclid-mou-collaboration-6de6bc54.md). CMBX-SWG is coordinating with WL-SWG on blinding; CMBX is listed as a potential unblinding authority. People: Cail Daley (data), Margherita Lembo (co-lead, gctools), Louis Legrand (co-lead, likelihood), Giulio Fabbian (SWG science lead), Emma Ayçoberry.

fibers.title: Data
fibers.body:
Three surveys on the southern sky, cross-correlated where their footprints overlap. All maps at HEALPix nside=2048 (RING), masked with C2 apodization at 0.15 deg. Overlap areas (mask > 0.95): ACT × Euclid 261 deg², SPT × Euclid 115 deg², triple overlap 74 deg².

**Euclid RR2 weak lensing.** Catalog `rr2_v2_1_wl_031224`: ~50M galaxies over 385 deg² effective footprint, split into 6 tomographic bins (mean redshift 0.52--1.72). Two independent shear pipelines — LensMC (forward-model) and Metacal (image-differencing) — provide e1/e2 per galaxy. Galaxy density from GC catalog (`catalogRR2_v2_GC_031124`): ~30M galaxies in 6 bins (mean z 0.31--0.89). Eleven VMPZ-ID systematic maps at nside 16384 track observational systematics (stellar density, galactic extinction, PSF, noise, persistence, etc.). Caveat: RR2 WL calibration columns (multiplicative bias m, additive bias c, calibrated weights) are all NaN — no shear calibration applied.

**ACT DR6 CMB lensing.** Convergence (κ) reconstructed via minimum-variance quadratic estimator from temperature and polarization (Qu+ 2023, Madhavacheril+ 2023). Total sky 9,400 deg² (fsky ≈ 0.23). The official apodized mask has a 3 deg cosine-squared rolloff. Noise power spectrum N_L provided per mode; Wiener-filtered κ map is the baseline product.

**SPT-3G winter CMB lensing.** Deep but narrow: ~1,550 deg² total, 115 deg² overlap with Euclid. Four estimator variants sharing the same footprint: GMV (baseline, highest S/N), TT (temperature-only, most tSZ-sensitive), PP (polarization-only, foreground-free), MV (standard minimum variance). Comparing TT−PP and GMV−PP isolates potential foreground bias. Approximate N₀ computed from auto-minus-cross of 11 simulations; proper noise curves pending from SPT. κ amplitude range ±0.062 (roughly 2× noisier than ACT).

**Redshift distributions.** n(z) from `RR2_v2_Nz_WL_C2020_sel_pv.fits` (3000-point grid, z = 0–6, sum-normalized per bin). Theory C_ℓ uses raw FITS n(z) — smoothing procedure not yet confirmed.

Sub-nodes: Euclid RR2 maps (`euclid-rr2-maps-0d4db3db`), CMB lensing maps (`cmb-lensing-maps-e7e9436c`) → ACT DR6 (`act-dr6-lensing-e4a3eae9`), SPT-3G winter (`spt-3g-winter-lensing-ab712d17`), Euclid n(z) (`euclid-n-z-d8d52b17`), shared conventions (`maps-shared-conventions-and-c4fac8e3`).

fibers.title: Methods
fibers.body:
Angular cross-power spectra are estimated via the NaMaster pseudo-Cℓ formalism (Alonso+ 2019), which corrects for mode-coupling induced by partial-sky masks through a coupling matrix and decouples into bandpowers. This section describes the estimators, masking, and covariance used throughout the analysis.

## Pseudo-Cℓ estimation

We measure cross-power spectra C^{fκ}_ℓ between Euclid tracers (shear γ or galaxy density δ) and CMB lensing convergence κ. All spectra are computed at nside=2048, lmax=3000, using 20 linearly-spaced bandpowers.

### Map-based estimator (production)

The production estimator operates on HEALPix maps. Shear maps enter NaMaster as spin-2 fields (`NmtField` with `pol_conv="IAU"`, lmax=3000); density overdensity maps and CMB κ maps enter as spin-0 fields. The mode-coupling matrix is computed from the apodized mask geometry and cached via `joblib` hash of the mask alms — the expensive coupling matrix computation happens once per mask pair and is reused across tomographic bins and shear methods.

For shear: `make_field([e1_map, e2_map], mask, spin=2, pol_conv="IAU")`. For density: `make_field([delta_map], mask, spin=0)`. For CMB κ: `make_field([kappa_map], cmb_mask, spin=0)`.

Rules: `compute_cross_spectrum` (spectra.smk). Library: `dr1_cmbx.eDR1data.spectra` — `make_field()`, `get_spectrum()`, `get_workspace()`.

### Catalog-based estimator (validation)

The catalog estimator bypasses map-making entirely: `NmtFieldCatalog` takes individual galaxy positions and ellipticities as a point cloud and computes spherical harmonic transforms in position space. This eliminates pixelization artifacts. Agreement with the map estimator — median bandpower correlation r=0.998, A_lens consistent within 1σ for every bin — confirms that map construction introduces no measurable bias.

Covariance for the catalog path uses an auxiliary map-based `NmtField` from the same shear maps, since `NmtFieldCatalog.get_mask()` raises ValueError. The covariance depends on mask geometry and auto-spectra, not the measurement method, so this is valid.

Rule: `compute_catalog_cross_spectrum` (explorations.smk). ~8 GB, 3-4 min/job at lmax=3000.

## Masking and apodization

Partial-sky pseudo-Cℓ estimation requires apodized masks to suppress spectral ringing from sharp survey boundaries. Four input masks — Euclid shear (continuous weights × binary footprint), Euclid density (binary), ACT DR6 (pre-apodized with 3° cosine-squared rolloff), and SPT-3G (border-apodized) — are C2-apodized at 0.15 rad (~8.6°), producing 10 mask products: 4 individual + 6 pairwise cross-products.

Shear masks: `footprint × weight_map → C2(0.15)`. The continuous weight map creates a smooth taper. Density masks: binary footprint → C2(0.15), producing only a ~9 arcmin edge taper. CMB masks: pre-apodized by experiment + additional 0.15° C2 pass (negligible for ACT, shapes SPT border).

Effective sky fractions (Hivon fsky_eff): shear×ACT 0.70%, shear×SPT 0.32%, density×ACT 0.67%, density×SPT 0.30%.

Rules: `build_rr2_apodized_masks`, `build_apodized_pair_masks` (maps.smk). Library: `make_mask()`, `make_cmb_mask()`.

## Covariance estimation

Two independent estimates validate each other:

**Knox formula** (primary for all χ²/PTE/S/N): `Var(C^{ab}_b) = C^{aa}_b · C^{bb}_b / n_modes_b` where `n_modes = Σ(2ℓ+1) · fsky_eff` with `fsky_eff = <w1·w2>² / <w1²·w2²>` (Hivon+ 2002 Eq. 17). Analytic, immune to coupling matrix numerics.

**NaMaster Gaussian** (error bars in plots): Uses the Improved Narrow Kernel Approximation (INKA) with theory+noise guess spectra. For spin-2 × spin-0, output is `(2·nbins, 2·nbins)` with interleaved E/B components — extracted via `extract_covariance_block` to the `(nbins, nbins)` E-mode block. Known artifact: last bandpower (ℓ≈2700) has near-zero variance from coupling matrix numerics (~1000× below Knox). This is why Knox is used for quantitative inference.

NaMaster/Knox ratio: 1.04 median for density (spin-0), ~1.26 for shear (spin-2). The >1 ratio reflects mode coupling from partial sky mixing power between bins — expected behavior.

## Implementation

Core library: `dr1_cmbx.eDR1data.spectra` (`cmbx/files/code_dr1_cmbx_src_dr1_cmbx_eDR1data_spectra.py`). Key functions: `make_mask()`, `make_field()`, `make_catalog_field()`, `get_spectrum()`, `map2cls()`, `get_workspace()`, `compute_knox_variance()`, `extract_covariance_block()`.

Snakemake rules: `compute_cross_spectrum` (production), `compute_catalog_cross_spectrum` (validation), `build_rr2_apodized_masks`, `build_apodized_pair_masks`, `compute_systematic_cross_spectrum`.

fibers.title: Validation
fibers.body:
Validation proceeds through four pillars: theory consistency (do the measured spectra match Planck 2018 ΛCDM?), cross-experiment and cross-pipeline consistency (do ACT and SPT agree? lensmc and metacal?), null tests (jackknife, simulation, B-mode), and systematic contamination analysis (11 VMPZ-ID maps, bias budget, harmonic-space contamination metric, and template marginalization).

Both tracers pass validation for ACT after the Euclid position-angle sign convention fix (`pol_conv="EUCLID"` → [-e1, +e2] for NaMaster). Density × κ: A_lens = 1.049 ± 0.063 (χ²/dof = 1.07, PTE = 0.28); all null tests consistent with zero; template marginalization yields A_lens = 0.986 ± 0.122. Shear × κ: A_lens = 0.880 ± 0.052 (lensmc × ACT, 17σ), 0.850 ± 0.055 (metacal × ACT, 15σ) — detected with chi2/dof = 0.92 and 0.97 respectively. SPT shows a 15–20% deficit for all tracers (density A_lens = 0.857 ± 0.050, lensmc = 0.694 ± 0.045, metacal = 0.697 ± 0.048) that persists after template marginalization — a CMB-side normalization issue under investigation (`spt-deficit-characterization-6b724e41`).

Fourteen nodes populate this section, organized by concern. The density systematic budget is severe (galactic extinction up to 12.6σ bias for ACT, stellar density 6.3σ) — template marginalization is mandatory for density. Shear systematics are clean (median χ²/dof = 1.29, 74% pass). B-mode covariance is approximate: NaMaster Gaussian underestimates BB variance at partial sky by 15–150× due to E→B leakage (`namaster-gaussian-covariance-9373b1fa`). Template marginalization is implemented via Fisher matrix joint fit in `evaluate_deprojected_likelihood`.

fibers.title: Results
fibers.body:
Both cross-correlations — galaxy density × CMB κ and cosmic shear × CMB κ — are detected at high significance with ACT DR6, validating the full Euclid × CMB lensing pipeline against Planck 2018 ΛCDM. SPT-3G shows a persistent 15–20% amplitude deficit across all tracers, pointing to a CMB-side normalization issue rather than a galaxy-side problem.

**Density × κ.** A_lens = 1.049 ± 0.063 (ACT, χ²/dof = 1.07), 0.857 ± 0.050 (SPT). ACT is fully consistent with Planck 2018 (A_lens = 1). Per-bin Knox S/N: 3.1, 6.3, 6.8, 6.7, 11.9, 9.7 (ACT). Template marginalization over 11 systematic maps yields A_lens = 0.986 ± 0.122 (ACT), 0.812 ± 0.122 (SPT) — density is robust to systematic contamination despite severe galaxy-density correlations with observational depth.

**Shear × κ.** A_lens = 0.880 ± 0.052 (lensmc × ACT, 17σ), 0.850 ± 0.055 (metacal × ACT, 15σ) with χ²/dof = 0.92 and 0.97. Both shear pipelines agree within 1σ. Prior to the Euclid position-angle sign convention fix (`pol_conv="EUCLID"` → [-e1, +e2]), A_lens ≈ 0.06 — the sign bug was the dominant systematic, now resolved (`shear-sign-convention-test-b751c2ca`). SPT shear: A_lens = 0.694 ± 0.045 (lensmc), 0.697 ± 0.048 (metacal). Deprojected (template marginalization): lensmc × ACT 0.824 ± 0.095, metacal × ACT 0.780 ± 0.097.

**Per-bin structure.** Signal rises with redshift as expected from the CMB lensing kernel. Shear per-bin S/N: 1.5, 0.7, 3.1, 7.1, 12.2, 17.7 (lensmc × ACT) — high-z bins dominate. Theory comparison χ²/dof degrades with z for shear (1.3 at bin 1 → 17 at bin 6) while density ≈ 1.0 everywhere — a z-dependent shear calibration issue, possibly related to the unvalidated RR2 multiplicative bias correction (m/c columns all NaN, `rr2-wl-catalog-calibration-5ee5e957`).

**SPT deficit.** The 15–20% amplitude deficit is consistent across density, lensmc, and metacal — ruling out galaxy-side causes. Under investigation (`spt-deficit-characterization-6b724e41`). The approximate SPT N₀ from auto-minus-cross may contribute.

fibers.title: Euclid catalog
fibers.body:
The Euclid RR2 weak lensing and galaxy clustering catalogs. WL: ~50M galaxies measured with lensmc and metacal shear pipelines, 6 tomographic bins defined by photometric redshift. GC: ~30M galaxies, 6 bins spanning z̄ ≈ 0.31–0.89 — shallower than WL (z̄ ≈ 0.52–1.72), reflecting the photometric selection for clustering. Catalog inputs: `euclid/catalogs/rr2_v2_1_wl_031224/` (WL), `euclid/catalogs/catalogRR2_v2_GC_031124.parquet` (GC). Both feed into map-building rules producing the HEALPix maps in [Euclid RR2 maps](.felt/euclid-rr2-maps-0d4db3db.md).

**Figure** (`euclid_nz_overview.png`): Two-panel plot of n(z) for WL (left) and GC (right). Each panel shows 6 tomographic bins as filled curves, normalized to unit area (∫n(z)dz = 1) over a 3000-point grid from z=0 to z=6. Curves drawn from the theoretical pipeline n(z) stored in `RR2_v2_Nz_WL/GC_C2020_sel_pv.fits` (columns BIN_ID, MEAN_REDSHIFT, N_Z). Mean redshift annotated per bin in the legend.

**Open: n(z) smoothing** — the theoretical n(z) arrays from the FITS files are noisy/jagged in the tails. The correct smoothing procedure for use in the theory C_ℓ calculation is not yet confirmed. Check Slack for the established RR2 convention (Margherita / WL-SWG n(z) thread). Until resolved, theory C_ℓ uses the raw FITS n(z).

fibers.title: CMB mask apodization
fibers.body:
Both ACT DR6 and SPT-3G winter lensing masks arrive already apodized — ACT has a 3° cos² rolloff (Qu+ 2023 Sec 5.3), SPT has its own smooth border apodization. Our pipeline additionally applies `nmt.mask_apodization(mask, 0.15, "C2")` — a 9 arcminute second pass that is negligible (max pixel difference 6×10⁻⁴, rms 3×10⁻⁵, zero fsky change). At present this does no harm and matches gctools conventions.

**Open issue — fsky_eff and mask powers**: For the Gaussian covariance, the effective sky fraction is `fsky_eff = <w_A² w_B²> / (<w_A²><w_B²>)` (Hivon+ 2002), which involves the *product* of squared masks. The broader apodization of the CMB masks (3° rolloff) means the fsky_eff for the cross-spectrum is set by the CMB mask geometry, not just the Euclid footprint. More importantly, the covariance requires the power spectrum of the mask product — a broader CMB apodization changes the mask power spectrum (smoother → less coupling between modes), and potentially shifts power into the C^BB_ℓ terms for spin-2 fields. This needs to be accounted for properly once we move from approximate Gaussian covariance to simulation-based covariance. For now the NaMaster Gaussian covariance handles this via the actual mask maps passed in, so it is correct by construction — but the fsky_eff diagnostic quoted in evidence files uses a Knox approximation that may underestimate uncertainty near the mask edges.

**Decision**: Keep current double-apodization (negligible effect, gctools consistency). Flag the fsky_eff/mask-power accounting as an open item for when we upgrade from Gaussian to simulation covariance.
fibers.outcome: Keep double-apodization: CMB masks arrive pre-apodized (ACT 3deg cos2, SPT smooth border), our additional 9arcmin C2 pass is negligible (max pixel diff 6e-4, rms 3e-5, zero fsky change). Consistent with gctools convention. fsky_eff and mask-power accounting are correct by construction in NaMaster Gaussian covariance (actual masks passed in). Knox fsky_eff proxy may slightly underestimate uncertainty near mask edges — flagged for future simulation-based covariance upgrade.

fibers.title: Evidence output field
fibers.outcome: Tapestry artifacts only render if listed in top-level 'output' field of evidence.json — e.g. {"id": "...", "output": {"png": "plot.png"}, "evidence": {...}}. save_evidence() in plot_utils.py wraps snakemake outputs under 'provenance.output', NOT the top level. Any script that calls save_evidence(flat_dict, ...) without wrapping it will produce evidence with no renderable artifacts. Fix: always pass {"id": ..., "output": {"png": name}, "evidence": flat_dict} as the first argument. Affected: plot_euclid_nz_overview.py was missing this and the plot didn't appear in tapestry sidebar.

fibers.title: Apodization plot convention
fibers.outcome: When visualizing apodization, plot the mask itself (0→1 taper) rather than data×mask. For density maps (δ ∈ [-1,1], zero mean), the apodized edges blend into the map's own zero-mean distribution and the taper is invisible. For shear weight maps (values 250–1300), zero is far from the mean so it's visible — but that's weight variation, not the apodization. Fixed euclid_rr2_maps_apodized.png to show make_shear_mask() and make_convergence_mask() outputs directly.

fibers.title: Pipeline formalization
fibers.body:
## Desired State

The analysis pipeline is a single coherent system — legible, reproducible, and still alive. Every computation flows through shared library code, formalized Snakemake rules, and shared utilities. There is one way to do each thing, and it's the right way.

This is built layer by layer, each layer checking the one beneath it. Formalizing cross-spectra reveals gaps in masking. Formalizing plotting reveals inconsistencies in how spectra are stored. The iteration works *downward* as much as forward — reassessing foundations as the structure grows.

New analysis may emerge. When it does, grapple with the results, document the decision, continue. Formalization makes the instrument more trustworthy, not more rigid.

## Rhythm

This is a collaboration. The human steers, reshaping the constitution as understanding deepens. Ralph surveys, proposes, implements. The interaction is where taste lives.

Each iteration:

1. **Survey** — What is stable? Where to build? Use `felt ls`, `felt show`, `felt upstream`, `felt downstream`. Check `felt downstream pipeline-formalization-db91ef79` for queued work. Read open and active fibers.

2. **Choose** — Highest-value intervention. Propose before acting on anything substantial.

3. **Implement and run** — Make the change, verify the DAG with `snakemake -n`, then actually run. Shepherd SLURM jobs to completion — sleep, check, repeat. Don't exit hoping the next iteration picks it up. A fiber is NOT done until computation has produced output.

4. **Reflect on results** — Read the plots. What are they *saying*? Do numbers make sense? Does a figure answer the question it was supposed to answer? Previous decisions can and should be revisited based on evidence. Writing code that compiles is not completion.

5. **Weave the tapestry** — Not a cleanup step — woven through the work. Close fibers with outcomes as you go. Open new ones as things emerge. Every tapestry fiber must have a lede paragraph — not a sentence, a real paragraph that orients a reader: what question this node answers, what was found, and why it matters. One-sentence stub fibers are not acceptable.


### The layers

1. **Library** — `dr1_cmbx.eDR1data` (maps_refactor branch, now live). Authoritative. Use the highest-level function that applies: `map2cls()` for end-to-end, `get_spectrum()` for single pairs. Don't reimplement what the library does.
2. **Scratch library** — `dr1_notebooks/scratch/cdaley/`. Growing analysis library: `spectrum_utils`, `plot_utils`, `snakemake_helpers`. `nmt_utils` stripped to `load_systematic_map` only — everything else now calls `dr1_cmbx` or `nmt` directly.
3. **Compute rules** — Snakemake rules calling library functions → NPZ outputs. Import from `dr1_cmbx` and scratch, not from each other.
4. **Plot rules** — NPZ → figures + evidence. Wildcard explosion is the enemy. One composite per scientific question, not one plot per combination. The goal is a handful of figures a collaborator can absorb in a meeting.
5. **Rule structure** — `rules/maps.smk`, `rules/spectra.smk`, `rules/systematics.smk`, `rules/tapestry.smk` = production. `rules/explorations.smk` = research front. Everything that isn't production-ready lives in explorations.

### What NOT to do

- Don't speculatively improve `maps_refactor` — but if a real gap surfaces (something the library didn't anticipate, or a clear bug), file it and fix it.
- Don't add abstraction for a single use. A function used once belongs inline; a function used three times belongs in the library.
- Don't close fibers until computation has run and you have read the results.

## Production Pipeline

The pipeline is mature. All layers are computed, all evidence current as of 2026-02-25. The DAG is clean (`snakemake -n` reports nothing to do). The default target and `generate_results_table` both complete.

### Layers

| Layer | Rules | Status |
|-------|-------|--------|
| Maps | `catalog_to_map`, `build_density_map` | Complete |
| Masks | `build_rr2_apodized_masks`, `build_apodized_pair_masks` | Complete |
| Spectra | `compute_cross_spectrum`, `combine_shear_cross_spectra`, `combine_density_cross_spectra` | Complete |
| Theory | `compute_theory_cls`, `compute_cmb_noise_curve` | Complete |
| Systematics | `compute_systematic_cross_spectrum`, `compute_cmbk_systematic_cross_spectrum` | Complete |
| Data docs | `plot_euclid_rr2_maps`, `plot_wiener_filter_validation` | Complete |
| Validation | `plot_act_vs_spt`, `plot_method_comparison`, `plot_theory_comparison`, `plot_redshift_trend`, `plot_signal_overview`, `plot_catalog_vs_map_composite` | Complete |
| Null tests | `plot_jackknife_null_test`, `plot_sim_null_test`, `plot_spatial_variation` | Complete |
| Systematics plots | `plot_systematic_null_tests`, `plot_contamination_metric`, `plot_systematic_budget`, `plot_deprojected_spectra`, `plot_systematic_spectra` | Complete |
| Likelihood | `evaluate_fiducial_likelihood`, `evaluate_deprojected_likelihood` | Complete |
| Results | `generate_results_table`, `plot_analysis_summary` | Complete |
| SPT estimators | `plot_spt_estimator_composite` | Complete |

### Science-blocked items

- **Shear non-detection** — A_lens ≈ 0.06 (lensmc), 0.11 (metacal). Awaiting collaborator input on shear response correction (`rr2-shear-response-correction-74e90e52`).
- **SPT normalization deficit** — A_lens = 0.857 (14% low). CMB-side origin confirmed. Needs SPT team input.
- **B-mode covariance** — NaMaster Gaussian BB underestimates by 15-150×. Proper covariance needs simulations (ACT×DES used 511 sims).

## Plot Standards

Every production plot follows `plotting-standards-57ba2ceb`. Run `felt show plotting-standards-57ba2ceb` for the full spec before writing or reviewing any plot script.

- **No per-wildcard output** that isn't individually earned. Per-bin, per-experiment plots stay in explorations.
- **Evidence**: every tapestry plot calls `save_evidence()` with a top-level `"output"` field so the dashboard renders the artifact.

## Context

### Architecture

```
dr1_cmbx.eDR1data           (maps_refactor — authoritative library)
    spectra.py: map2cls(), get_spectrum(), make_mask(), make_field()
    maps.py:    process_shear_catalog(), write_sparse_map()
        ↓
dr1_notebooks.scratch.cdaley
    spectrum_utils, plot_utils, snakemake_helpers, nmt_utils(load_systematic_map only)
        ↓
workflow/scripts/             (compute + plot scripts)
        ↓
workflow/Snakefile + rules/{maps,spectra,systematics,tapestry,explorations}.smk
        ↓
config/config.yaml
```

### Production vs exploration

Rules that produce data consumed by other rules → production. Rules that produce figures or evidence for human inspection → exploration, unless they are named in the production pipeline above.

## Skills

ALWAYS activate ALL of these at the start of every iteration:
- `/snakemake` — rule definitions, execution, DAG discipline
- `/tapestry` — evidence conventions, narrative state
- `/implementing-code` — code quality
- `/writing` — when modifying fiber bodies, outcomes, or any prose

## Reading fibers and plots

Every iteration: read the fibers, look at the actual plots. Not skim — read. Ask: does this plot answer the question the fiber poses? Is the stated outcome still true given current data? Is the framing sharp or hedged? Does the figure follow plotting standards?

Then decide: does this need better writing, reframing, rerunning, or a new plot? A fiber whose plot is stale (from before a pipeline fix, a sign-convention correction, a mask change) must be flagged and rerun. A closed fiber whose outcome no longer matches the evidence must be reopened.

This is not a cleanup step. It is the work.

## Git hygiene

`code/dr1_notebooks/` — rapid exploration, single user. Every iteration: commit all changes, even from previous work. Don't leave dirty state.

`code/dr1_cmbx/` — shared library. Don't commit here unless explicitly asked.

## Mindset

The pipeline is mature. FITS→pickle migration complete, shear sign convention resolved. The work now is: (1) keep the full DAG clean (generate_results_table, not just core), (2) respond when collaborator input unblocks science questions, (3) maintain accuracy of fibers and evidence as understanding evolves, (4) be ready for new analysis directions (TR1→DR1 transition, new systematics, response correction).

## Focus areas

Five spine nodes (tier:1): Introduction → Data → Methods → Validation → Results. All carry narrative prose. 31 interior tapestry nodes closed with evidence. Findings synthesis (`findings-synthesis-euclid-cmb-03354e57`) is the comprehensive document.

- **SPT transfer function**: Is the 14% deficit in κ normalization or scale-dependent bias?
- **B-mode covariance**: NaMaster Gaussian BB is unreliable at fsky ~ 0.01. Simulation-based covariance needed for formal B-mode null test.

## Evidence


fibers.title: Apodization Layer
fibers.body:
Partial-sky pseudo-Cℓ estimation requires apodized masks to suppress spectral ringing from sharp survey boundaries. This layer takes four input masks — Euclid shear (continuous weights × binary footprint), Euclid density (binary), ACT DR6 (pre-apodized with 3° cosine-squared rolloff), and SPT-3G (border-apodized) — and produces the 10 C2-apodized products needed by the estimators: 4 individual masks plus all 6 pairwise cross-products (shear×ACT, shear×SPT, density×ACT, density×SPT, ACT×SPT, shear×density). The apodization kernel is C2 at 0.15 rad (~8.6°), following gctools conventions. Effective sky fractions are small: shear×ACT 0.70%, shear×SPT 0.32%, density×ACT 0.67%, density×SPT 0.30% — driven by the intersection of Euclid's ~385 deg² RR2 footprint with the CMB lensing patches.

Two Snakemake rules implement this: `build_rr2_apodized_masks` (the 10 shared masks) and `build_apodized_pair_masks` (per-bin per-CMB pair masks for the estimators). Downstream: [Map Harmonic Estimator](.felt/map-based-harmonic-space-5f227b0f.md) consumes these masks via `make_mask()` and `make_cmb_mask()` in `dr1_cmbx.eDR1data.spectra`.
fibers.outcome: Apodization infrastructure complete: build_rr2_apodized_masks produces 10 C2-apodized mask FITS (shear, density, ACT, SPT, and all pairwise cross-products) from 4 input masks. Effective fsky: shear×ACT 0.70%, shear×SPT 0.32%, density×ACT 0.67%, density×SPT 0.30%. Shear support_fraction (0.93%) exceeds effective_fraction anomalously — weight variability inflates the support relative to Hivon effective area; density (binary weights) shows the expected support > effective ordering. Per-bin per-CMB pair masks built by build_apodized_pair_masks. Memory tuned: density_map at 4–24 GB (bin-dependent), rr2_apodized at 24 GB. Remaining open question: whether 0.15° aposcale is optimal (tracked in choose-additional-c2-aposcale-5cdf0511).

fibers.title: Wiener filter validation
fibers.body:
Two-panel diagnostic for the CMB lensing noise regime. Panel (a): C_ℓ^map for ACT/SPT and residuals |C_ℓ^map − C_ℓ^{κκ,theory}| against Planck 2018 theory, showing where signal exceeds noise. Panel (b): theory-informed Wiener filter W(ℓ) from published noise curves.

The filter quantifies the ℓ range where cross-correlation is signal-dominated. For ACT, this is ℓ < 145; for SPT, the N₀ is too noisy from only 11 sims to characterize cleanly, but the trend is similar. This sets expectations for the bandpower S/N in the cross-spectra: most information comes from ℓ < 200.

**Script**: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_wiener_filter_validation.py`
fibers.outcome: Theory-informed Wiener filter W(ℓ) = C_ℓ^{κκ} / (C_ℓ^{κκ} + N_ℓ) using published ACT N_L and computed SPT N₀ (11 sims). ACT peaks at W≈0.7 near ℓ~60, crosses 0.5 at ℓ~145. SPT N₀ noisy at low ℓ (only 11 sims). Both experiments noise-dominated at ℓ>200.

fibers.title: Catalog estimator
fibers.body:
## Catalog-based harmonic cross-spectrum estimator

The catalog estimator computes shear × CMB-κ cross-spectra directly from galaxy catalogs, bypassing pixelization entirely. It is the validation estimator — not production — living in `compute_catalog_cross_spectrum` (explorations.smk). Its agreement with the map estimator (median bandpower correlation 0.998) proves that map-making introduces no bias.

### Construction

`nmt.NmtFieldCatalog` takes galaxy positions and ellipticities directly:

```python
make_catalog_field(
    pos=[ra, dec],          # (2, N) in degrees, lonlat=True
    weights=w,              # she_{method}_weight, shape (N,)
    values=[e1, e2],        # she_{method}_e{1,2}_corrected
    lmax=3000,              # config: cross_correlation.binning.lmax
    spin=2,                 # shear
    pol_conv="IAU",         # Euclid native; no e2 flip
)
```

Before field creation, additive bias is subtracted per component: `e_i -= <e_i>_w` (weighted mean). The subtracted values are stored in evidence metadata (`c1_subtracted`, `c2_subtracted`).

Filtering chain: `tom_bin_id == bin_id`, `weight > 0`, `.drop_nulls()`. Typical catalog size: 100k–500k galaxies per bin (from ~5M total RR2).

### Covariance

`NmtFieldCatalog.get_mask()` raises `ValueError` — NaMaster cannot access the implicit mask. This blocks both workspace caching and Gaussian covariance computation.

**Solution**: build an auxiliary map-based `NmtField` from the same underlying shear maps. The auxiliary field is used only for the covariance workspace; the cross-spectrum itself comes from the catalog field. This is valid because the NaMaster Gaussian covariance depends on mask geometry and fiducial spectra, not on the measurement method.

**Knox proxy** is also available as a diagnostic. For catalog fields, shape noise is computed directly from the weighted ellipticity variance: `σ²_e = np.average(e², weights=w)`, with effective number density `n_eff = (Σw)² / Σw² / Ω_cross`.

### Workspace caching

Map-based fields hash via `joblib.hash([field.get_mask(), field.spin])` → cached to `.nmt_workspaces/`. Catalog fields return `None` for the hash (no `get_mask()`) → workspace is computed fresh each run. This makes catalog jobs slower (~3-4 min vs ~1-2 min for map).

### Polarization convention

Euclid shear catalogs are in IAU convention natively. The `pol_conv="IAU"` parameter tells NaMaster to handle the IAU→internal conversion transparently. No manual e2 flip is needed.

### What the catalog estimator tests

By operating on galaxy positions and ellipticities without pixelization, it isolates map-making artifacts: HEALPix discretization, sparse FITS encoding, weight map construction, and mask edge effects. Agreement with the map estimator at the 0.2% level (r = 0.998) confirms that none of these introduce bias. The agreement is a strict consistency check — both estimators share the same CMB κ map, so the test is galaxy-side only.

### Code path

`cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_compute_cross_spectrum.py` lines 151–223 (catalog branch). Called by `compute_catalog_cross_spectrum` rule in `cmbx/files/workflow_rules_explorations.smk` with `estimator="catalog"`.
fibers.outcome: Validation estimator documented. NmtFieldCatalog operates directly on galaxy positions and ellipticities (no pixelization). IAU pol_conv, lmax=3000, additive bias subtracted per component. Covariance via auxiliary map-based field (NmtFieldCatalog.get_mask() raises ValueError). Workspace not cacheable — computed fresh each run (~3-4 min/job). Agreement with map estimator at r=0.998 confirms map-making introduces no bias. Code unified: both estimators share compute_cross_spectrum.py.

fibers.title: Map estimator
fibers.body:
## Map-based harmonic cross-spectrum estimator

The map estimator is the production estimator. It computes cross-spectra from pixelized HEALPix maps via `nmt.NmtField` → pseudo-C_ℓ → mode-decoupled bandpowers. All production cross-spectra (shear × κ, density × κ) use this path.

### Pipeline

1. **Map building** (`catalog_to_map` rule): Euclid shear catalogs → sparse HEALPix FITS at nside=2048. Two maps per method per bin: e1, e2 components + weight map. Loaded via `nmt_utils.read_healpix_map()` which handles both dense and sparse FITS.

2. **Masking** (`make_mask` / `make_shear_mask` / `make_convergence_mask`):
   - Shear: `footprint(weight > 0) × weight_map` → C2 apodize at 0.15 rad. The continuous weight gradients produce visually smooth masks.
   - Density: `footprint(mask > 0)` → C2 apodize at 0.15 rad. Binary input produces only a ~9 arcmin edge taper.
   - CMB κ: ACT uses official apodized mask (downgraded from nside=4096); SPT uses winter mask with 3° cos² rolloff. Direct apodization via `nmt.mask_apodization()`.

3. **Field construction** (`make_field`):
   ```python
   nmt.NmtField(mask, [e1, e2], spin=2, pol_conv="IAU", lmax=3000, n_iter=1)
   ```
   Shear: spin-2 with IAU convention (Euclid native — no e2 flip). Density/convergence: spin-0. CMB κ: spin-0.

4. **Cross-spectrum**: `nmt.compute_coupled_cell(euclid_field, cmbk_field)` → coupled pseudo-C_ℓ. Decoupled via workspace: `wksp.decouple_cell(pcl)`. Output: (2, nbins) for spin-2 × spin-0 [E-κ, B-κ], (1, nbins) for spin-0 × spin-0.

5. **Binning**: Log-spaced, 20 bandpowers from ℓ=40 to ℓ=3000. Edges: `np.geomspace(40, 3000, 21)`.

### Covariance

NaMaster Gaussian approximation with theory + noise fiducial spectra:
- Shear auto: `C_ℓ^{EE,theory} + σ²/n_eff` (shape noise from FITS header `NOISE_CL`)
- CMB auto: `C_ℓ^{κκ,theory} + N_ℓ` (reconstruction noise from published curves)
- Cross: `C_ℓ^{Eκ,theory}`

Spin-2 × spin-0 covariance output is (2×nbins, 2×nbins) with EE/BB interleaved. Extracted via `extract_covariance_block(cov, nbins)` → `(nbins, nbins)` E-κ covariance.

Validated against Knox formula: NaMaster/Knox ≈ 1.04 (density), ≈ 1.26 (shear). NaMaster is primary for all error bars.

### Workspace caching

Workspaces hash via `joblib.hash([field.get_mask(), field.spin])` — symmetric in field order. Cached to `.nmt_workspaces/wksp_cl/{hash}.fits`. Persistent across runs, significantly faster (~1-2 min/job vs ~3-4 for catalog).

### Code path

`cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_compute_cross_spectrum.py` lines 224–340 (map branch). Called by `compute_cross_spectrum` rule in `cmbx/files/workflow_rules_spectra.smk` with `estimator="map"`.
fibers.outcome: Production estimator documented. Pixelized HEALPix maps → NmtField(spin=2, pol_conv=IAU, lmax=3000) → pseudo-Cℓ → mode-decoupled bandpowers. Masking: footprint × weight → C2 apodize at 0.15 rad. Covariance: NaMaster Gaussian with theory+noise fiducial spectra, validated at NaMaster/Knox ≈ 1.04 (density) and 1.26 (shear). Workspace caching via field hash. 20 log-spaced bandpowers, ℓ=40–3000.

fibers.title: Tapestry DAG thinning
fibers.body:
Reorganize the tapestry DAG for legibility. Currently nodes have too many connections and the section boundaries are blurred. Three changes:

### 1. Theory nodes move to Results

Theory comparison, theory residuals, and likelihood evaluation are *results* — they answer "does the data match ΛCDM?" Move them from Validation to Results. Validation should be about consistency checks and null tests, not about the science answer.

### 2. Systematic contamination summary node

Currently individual systematic checks (null tests, bias budget, contamination metric, systematic spectra, deprojected spectra) all connect directly to the Validation spine. Instead, a single "Systematic contamination" summary node should sit between Validation and the individual checks. This node summarizes the overall contamination picture; the individual nodes are its children. Reduces Validation's direct connections and gives the contamination story a natural entry point.

### 3. Wire ACT/SPT data nodes to downstream results

The ACT DR6 (`act-dr6-lensing-e4a3eae9`) and SPT winter (`spt-3g-winter-lensing-ab712d17`) data doc fibers exist in the Data section but aren't connected to the downstream fibers that use those experiments (ACT vs SPT comparison, SPT deficit, estimator comparisons, etc.). The DAG should show this provenance — the data nodes are upstream of the results that depend on them.

### Legibility constraint

Aim for ~3 direct upstream/downstream connections per node. If a node has more, it's probably serving as a pass-through and something can be restructured. The DAG should be readable at a glance, not a hairball.
fibers.outcome: Rewired tapestry for legibility in three passes. (1) Theory ownership moved from Validation to Results by making theory_comparison, theory_residual_analysis, and evaluate_fiducial_likelihood downstream of Results and removing Validation as direct upstream. (2) Added summary node systematic-contamination-summary-e6c81e29 (tag tapestry:systematic_contamination_summary) between Validation and contamination-detail fibers: plot_systematic_null_tests, plot_contamination_metric, plot_systematic_spectra, plot_systematic_budget, and template_deprojection. (3) Added explicit ACT/SPT data provenance edges from act-dr6-lensing-e4a3eae9 and spt-3g-winter-lensing-ab712d17 into downstream results fibers: plot_act_vs_spt, overlap consistency, SPT estimator comparison, theory comparison, and SPT theory-fail node. fibers.title: Systematic contamination summary
fibers.body:
Observational systematics — variations in PSF size, exposure depth, stellar density, galactic extinction, zodiacal background — correlate with galaxy positions and shapes because the survey depth is not uniform. If a systematic map S correlates with both the galaxy field f and the CMB lensing field κ, the cross-spectrum C^{fκ} picks up a spurious contribution X = C^{κS} · C^{fS} / C^{SS} (the harmonic-space contamination metric of Omori+ 2022). For density, this contamination is severe: 0/77 systematic null tests pass (median χ²/dof = 50.8), with galactic extinction and stellar density contributing multi-σ integrated bias. For shear, the picture is clean: 114/154 pass (median χ²/dof = 1.29) — shape measurement is insensitive to most depth-correlated systematics because shear is a spin-2 quantity whose orientation doesn't track scalar survey properties.

The contamination analysis proceeds in five stages, each a downstream node: [systematic null tests](.felt/systematic-null-test-heatmap-92dec7e5.md) (per-bandpower spectral pulls), [contamination metric](.felt/contamination-metric-product-c-e55501f4.md) (per-bandpower X/σ ratios), [raw spectra](.felt/systematic-spectra-raw-c-fs-c-3d65264d.md) (the C^{fS}, C^{κS}, C^{SS} ingredients), [bias budget](.felt/systematic-bias-budget-709ea507.md) (integrated significance per systematic), and [template marginalization](.felt/template-deprojection-a1621797.md) (Fisher matrix joint fit absorbing contamination into the amplitude uncertainty). The key result: after marginalizing over 10 templates, density × ACT yields A_lens = 0.986 ± 0.122 (8.1σ) — consistent with Planck 2018 and robust to systematics.
fibers.outcome: Validation contamination entry point introduced for DAG legibility: contamination storyline is summarized here, with detailed checks as downstream children (null pulls, contamination metric, raw spectra, bias budget, and template deprojection).

The current analysis summary is a one-page poster of fixed metrics. Synthesis is different: it's a living fiber that weaves threads from Data, Methods, Validation, and Results into a coherent understanding of where the analysis stands. What do we know? What's unresolved? What's surprising? It grows and changes as the analysis deepens — it's never "done."

The spine becomes: Introduction → Data → Methods → Validation → Results → Synthesis.

fibers.title: Map/catalog amplitude gap
fibers.outcome: On Monday, February 23, 2026, we reran plot_catalog_validation_summary after formalizing a signal-selected fractional metric (|C_map|/sigma_map >= 1.0) alongside legacy RMS. This resolves the core amplitude-gap interpretation question: extreme RMS tails were largely denominator artifacts from near-zero map bandpowers. Evidence now shows legacy median RMS_frac=0.921 and p95=20.48, but signal-selected median RMS_frac_signal=0.201 and p95=0.789 (max 1.395), with the prior worst case (metacal bin2 x ACT) dropping from RMS_frac 64.9 to RMS_frac_signal 0.0187. The remaining tension is not a generic map-vs-catalog amplitude failure; it is concentrated ACT-driven chi2 outliers (e.g., lensmc bin2 x ACT chi2_nu~19.7, metacal bin1 x ACT chi2_nu~10.6), now tracked explicitly in act-dominated-map-catalog-chi2-19797f04.

fibers.title: Method chi2 calibration
fibers.outcome: The lensmc vs metacal chi2 test is uninformative in its current form. Composite comparison (6 bins x ACT) gives 0/6 pass at 5%, median chi2/dof=2.25. But the covariance model (sigma_diff = sqrt(sigma_lens^2 + sigma_meta^2)) is wrong: both methods share the same galaxies and CMB map, so errors are heavily correlated. The unknown cross-covariance makes the effective degrees of freedom undefined — chi2/dof=2.25 could indicate genuine disagreement or could be noise. Bins 1-2 show chi2/dof=20-25 (likely real differences in how lensmc and metacal respond to low-S/N galaxies at low z). Bins 3-6 show chi2/dof=1.6-2.3 (ambiguous). Proper calibration requires simulations with matched noise. Visually, the methods agree well — spectra overlap across all bins and scales.

fibers.title: ACT filter crossing
fibers.outcome: Resolved by Wiener filter rewrite (2026-02-25, commit 4469247). Previous empirical N_ℓ = C_ℓ^map/fsky - C_ℓ^{κκ,theory} was too noisy. Theory-informed W(ℓ) using published ACT N_L curve shows ACT peaks at W≈0.7 near ℓ~60 and crosses 0.5 at ℓ~145. Not below 0.5 everywhere — the ACT noise curve has a bowl shape (MV estimator optimized at intermediate ℓ). Filter is well-behaved when using the published reconstruction noise rather than a per-mode empirical estimate.

fibers.title: DAG shepherding persistence
fibers.body:
The blocking question is execution persistence for the broad `generate_results_table` DAG: we can launch and make steady progress, but the full 478-job span is multi-hour and requires uninterrupted shepherding that outlasts one interactive loop turn. On Monday, February 23, 2026, we verified the broad run and advanced it across multiple waves (e.g., 32/478 completed under SLURM run ID `f7f5b7d5-be50-402b-bb0c-88266707b673`), but this exposed a control-plane gap rather than a science-code bug: we need a durable shepherd mechanism that can survive loop handoff while still enforcing explicit sleep/poll/check discipline.

## Evidence from this iteration
- Dry-run at 09:19 showed `total 497` jobs for `snakemake -n generate_results_table -j20`.
- Active scheduler process observed: `snakemake -j20 generate_results_table`.
- First run dropped scheduler with `Will exit after finishing currently running jobs (scheduler)` while leaving submitted jobs to drain.
- Relaunched run at 09:24 under run ID `f7f5b7d5-be50-402b-bb0c-88266707b673`; observed repeated successful completions and new submissions through at least `32/478 steps`.
- To leave clean state before handoff, scheduler was stopped intentionally and in-flight queue drained to zero (09:34:45).

## Decision needed
Choose and formalize one persistent execution pattern for this broad DAG:
1. Keep a long-lived foreground shepherd session per iteration (strictly no exit until 100%).
2. Add a formal shepherd wrapper (script/rule) that loops `snakemake -> poll queue -> rerun` until target exists, with clear logging and failure detection.
3. Use a cluster-side persistent mechanism (e.g., dedicated SLURM shepherd job) with the same explicit polling semantics.

The goal is not to relax rigor; it is to make the rigorous 100%-completion requirement operationally sustainable.
fibers.outcome: Resolved. The full 478-job DAG completed across multiple shepherd runs. snakemake -n reports 'Nothing to be done' for both default target and generate_results_table. The persistence question was a control-plane gap (loop handoff), not a science-code issue — solved by breaking large runs into phases and using tmux detached sessions.

Reason: noise in the weighted map scales as Σw²σ²/(Σw)², so the effective per-galaxy variance is the w²-weighted mean of e². w-weighting overweights noisy (low-w) galaxies relative to their map contribution. The two estimators agree only when all weights are equal — they diverge significantly for LensMC where weights vary. Fixed in commit a8b21ec on maps_refactor.

fibers.title: B-mode excess at low ℓ
fibers.body:
Systematic negative B-mode excess at low ℓ in shear × κ cross-spectra. Two distinct features, both affecting all 6 tomographic bins and both shear methods (lensmc, metacal).

### Feature 1: ℓ ≈ 84, both ACT and SPT

Negative B-modes at 2.5–4.4σ (Knox) across bins 2–6 for both CMB experiments. Present in ACT and all four SPT estimators (GMV, TT, PP, MV). Since it appears in both CMB maps, the source is on the galaxy side — likely E→B leakage from partial-sky mode coupling. The overlap footprints are small (ACT∩Euclid 261 deg², SPT∩Euclid 115 deg²), making leakage significant at these scales.

Representative values at ℓ=84 (lensmc, B/σ_Knox):
- Bin 3: ACT −2.7, SPT GMV (not exceeding threshold at ℓ=84 specifically)
- Bin 4: ACT −2.7
- Bin 6: ACT −3.7, SPT GMV −3.7, SPT TT −4.4, SPT PP −3.6, SPT MV −3.9

### Feature 2: ℓ ≈ 44, SPT-specific

Negative B-modes at 2.5–4.3σ for bins 3–6, absent in ACT (ACT has |B/σ| < 1 at ℓ=44). Consistent across all four SPT estimators. Since SPT's overlap patch is smaller (fsky≈0.044), E→B leakage is expected to be more severe at the largest angular scales. Alternatively, this could be a large-scale systematic in the SPT winter κ reconstruction.

Raw values at ℓ=44 (lensmc bin6, map estimator):
- ACT: E=+2.3e-08, B=−1.3e-08 (−0.5σ)
- SPT GMV: E=+1.9e-08, B=−7.5e-08 (−2.4σ)
- SPT TT: E=+3.8e-09, B=−5.3e-08 (−1.5σ)
- SPT PP: E=+2.4e-08, B=−8.5e-08 (−2.5σ)
- SPT MV: E=+1.9e-08, B=−7.5e-08 (−2.4σ)

### Key observation

**All >2.5σ B-mode outliers are negative.** 56 excursions above 2.5σ across all bins/methods/experiments; every one is negative. Random scatter at this threshold would produce roughly equal positive and negative. This coherent sign points to a physical or geometric origin (E→B leakage produces a definite sign pattern depending on mask geometry).

### Interpretation

E→B leakage at partial sky is the leading explanation. NaMaster's pseudo-Cℓ formalism decouples E and B modes, but the decoupling is imperfect when fsky is small. Neither we, gctools, ACT×DES, nor DES×SPT use `purify_b=True`. ACT×DES (Qu+ 2023) used 511 sims for B-mode covariance instead of the NaMaster Gaussian approximation, which underestimates B-mode variance by 15–150× (see `namaster-gaussian-covariance-9373b1fa`).

The B-mode excess does NOT explain the shear non-detection — the E-mode signal itself is suppressed to ≈10% of theory, while B-modes at 10⁻⁸ are comparable to E-mode amplitudes (as expected from leakage at this sky fraction). The absence of E-mode signal is a separate problem.

### Next steps

- Confirm with `purify_b=True` run (expensive but diagnostic)
- Compare B-mode amplitudes to the E→B leakage prediction from the coupling matrix
- Note this in the methods discussion as a known limitation of partial-sky pseudo-Cℓ
fibers.outcome:
Two features in shear x kappa B-mode cross-spectra, both from E->B leakage at partial sky (fsky 0.01-0.03):

(1) ell~84 negative B-modes at 2.5-4.4sigma (Knox) across bins 2-6, BOTH ACT and SPT. Galaxy-side origin (both CMB maps see it). All four SPT estimators (GMV/TT/PP/MV) agree.

(2) ell~44 negative B-modes at 2.5-4.3sigma for bins 3-6 in SPT only, absent in ACT (|B/sigma|<1). SPT's smaller fsky (0.044 vs 0.248) amplifies low-ell leakage.

Key diagnostic: ALL 56 excursions above 2.5sigma are negative — coherent sign from mask geometry, not random scatter. B/E amplitude ratio 0.58-1.47 (B-modes comparable to E-modes, expected for E->B leakage at this sky fraction). NaMaster Gaussian BB covariance underestimates B-mode variance by 15-150x (does not capture leakage contributions). ACTxDES (Qu+ 2023) used 511 sims instead.

Does NOT explain the shear non-detection — E-mode signal itself is suppressed to ~10% of theory. The B-mode excess is a separate geometric effect from mask-induced mode coupling. Neither we, gctools, ACTxDES, nor DESxSPT use purify_b=True.

fibers.title: MR5 review fixes
fibers.body:
# MR !5 Review Fixes

Code review fixes for `dr1_cmbx` MR !5 (maps_refactor branch). These are concrete, enumerated changes — a set of laws, not aspirations.

## Desired State

Every item below is implemented, tested (where applicable), and the existing test suite still passes. No new files — all changes are edits to existing code.

### Law 1: WL noise stored as scalar

`process_wl_catalog` stores a **scalar** `noise_cl` (float) in the pickle, not an `nl_coupled` array. The array `(n_cls, lmax+1)` is built at the point of use — inside `map2cls` when consuming the WL pickle — using whatever `lmax` the current analysis requires.

**Why:** The noise is white (flat in ℓ). Storing `(1, 3*nside)` bakes in a length that may not match the analysis `lmax`. A scalar is the natural representation of flat noise and eliminates shape mismatches.

**Where:**
- `maps.py`: `process_wl_catalog` — replace `nl_coupled = noise_cl * fsky * np.ones((1, 3*nside))` with storing the scalar `noise_cl` (and `fsky` if needed) directly
- `spectra.py`: `map2cls` WL section (~line 1198) — build `nl_4 = np.zeros((4, lmax+1)); nl_4[0] = nl_4[3] = noise_scalar` from the stored scalar and the current `lmax`
- Tests: update any test that references `nl_coupled` shape

### Law 2: Verify workspace cache correctness

`get_workspace` uses `_hash_fields` (masks + spins only) as cache key, then calls `update_bins()` on load. This is correct NaMaster usage IF `check_unbinned()` / `update_bins()` work as documented — the coupling matrix is bin-independent and binning is applied during decoupling.

**Action:** Write a test that computes the same spectrum with two different binning schemes from the same cached workspace and verifies results match fresh (uncached) computation. If the test passes, the cache is correct and no hash change is needed. If it fails, add bins to the hash.

### Law 3: Remove dead filename code

Delete `_build_gc_filename` and `_exp_tag` from `spectra.py`. They are dead code — `map2cls` builds output filenames from input basenames (line ~1214). Remove their tests from `test_spectra.py` as well.

### Law 4: Rename `Bbl` → `bpws`

Unify on `bpws` throughout. Currently `get_spectrum` returns `"bpws"`, but `get_spectra` renames it to `"Bbl"` (line 806), and `pickle_spectra` reads `"Bbl"`. One name for one thing.

**Where:** `get_spectra` (line 806), `pickle_spectra` (~line 930), any test referencing `"Bbl"`.

### Law 5: Determine `nbin` from catalog data

`gc_cat2map` line 177: `tom_ids = cat["pos_tom_bin_id"].to_numpy(...) if nbin == 6 else np.ones_like(z, dtype=int)` — the `nbin == 6` gate is wrong. Read `pos_tom_bin_id` unconditionally (it's in the catalog regardless of how many bins we want) and let the downstream loop over `range(1, nbin+1)` select the relevant bins.

**Where:** `maps.py` `gc_cat2map` (~line 177). Remove the `if nbin == 6` conditional.

### Law 6: `extract_covariance_block` docstring

Update the docstring to document all three cases: spin-0×spin-0 (n_cls=1, returns as-is), spin-2×spin-0 (n_cls=2, extracts Eκ block), spin-2×spin-2 (n_cls=4, extracts EE block). The code already handles all three correctly.

### Law 7: `_hash_fields` — no silent error masking

The `except (ValueError, AttributeError)` clause is there for `NmtFieldCatalog` which raises on `get_mask()`. Narrow the catch: use `isinstance(f, nmt.NmtFieldCatalog)` to detect the catalog case explicitly and return `None` before attempting `get_mask()`. Let all other exceptions propagate. Nothing in this codebase should silently swallow errors.

### Law 8: Common mask TODO

Add a comment in `map2cls` at the `common_mask` block (~line 1130):
```python
# TODO: common_mask binarizes all inputs before intersection.
# For weighted (non-binary) masks, this discards weight information.
# Consider whether weighted intersection is needed.
```

### Law 9: `wl_cat2map` integration test

Add a test that exercises the full `wl_cat2map` pipeline: construct a small polars DataFrame with the expected columns (`right_ascension`, `declination`, `e1_cal`, `e2_cal`, `weight`, `tom_bin_id`, `tile_index`), run `wl_cat2map`, and verify the output pickle has the correct structure and values. Model on the existing `gc_cat2map` test pattern but without monkeypatching `process_wl_catalog`.

## Context

- **Repo:** `code/dr1_cmbx/` on `maps_refactor` branch
- **Key files:** `src/dr1_cmbx/eDR1data/spectra.py`, `src/dr1_cmbx/eDR1data/maps.py`, `tests/test_spectra.py`, `tests/test_maps.py`
- **Test runner:** `cd code/dr1_cmbx && pip install -e . && pytest tests/ -q` (inside container or CI)
- **NaMaster:** real NmtField objects at nside=8 in test fixture (`tests/conftest.py`). No mocking.

## Skills

Activate `/implementing-code` before working.

## Evidence

```bash
cd /leonardo_work/EUHPC_E05_083/cdaley00/cmbx/code/dr1_cmbx

# All tests pass
singularity exec --bind /leonardo_work/EUHPC_E05_083 /leonardo_work/EUHPC_E05_083/cdaley00/container \
  bash -c "cd /leonardo_work/EUHPC_E05_083/cdaley00/cmbx/code/dr1_cmbx && pip install -e . -q && pytest tests/ -q"

# Dead code is gone
grep -n '_build_gc_filename\|_exp_tag' src/dr1_cmbx/eDR1data/spectra.py  # should return nothing

# Bbl is gone
grep -rn 'Bbl' src/ tests/  # should return nothing

# nbin == 6 gate is gone
grep -n 'nbin == 6' src/dr1_cmbx/eDR1data/maps.py  # should return nothing

# nl_coupled array is gone from maps.py
grep -n 'nl_coupled.*ones' src/dr1_cmbx/eDR1data/maps.py  # should return nothing

# noise stored as scalar
grep -n 'noise_cl' src/dr1_cmbx/eDR1data/maps.py  # scalar storage
```

## Open Questions

None — all items are decided. Execute.

fibers.title: Shear-theory chi2 vs z
fibers.body:
After fixing theory comparison to use Knox variance (commit 4764901), chi2 vs Planck 2018 ΛCDM reveals a systematic pattern in shear × κ that doesn't appear in density × κ.

**Density × ACT**: chi2/dof ≈ 0.8-1.3 across all 6 bins. Excellent agreement.

**Shear (lensmc) × ACT**: chi2/dof = 1.3 (bin 1), 1.9 (bin 2), 2.0 (bin 3), 3.0 (bin 4), 6.9 (bin 5), 11.6 (bin 6). Degrades systematically with redshift.

**Shear (lensmc) × SPT GMV**: Same pattern, worse: chi2/dof = 1.3 (bin 1) → 17.1 (bin 6). Data at ℓ > 200 falls systematically below theory for high-z bins.

NLA IA makes no difference (IA chi2 ≈ vanilla chi2 in every bin).

Possible explanations:
1. Shear calibration bias worsening with z (multiplicative m bias in photo-z bins)
2. Shape noise estimation issue in high-z bins
3. Theory n(z) mismatch (wrong effective redshift for high bins)
4. E-mode leakage from B-modes (known to be large at fsky~0.1)
5. Knox variance underestimates true scatter at high z

Density passes because it's spin-0 (no E/B separation) and uses different weighting (number counts vs shape weights). The divergence between density and shear chi2 at high z is the key diagnostic.

Next: check plot_theory_residual_analysis for amplitude fits. If A_hat ≈ 1 but chi2 is bad, the issue is scatter/variance, not amplitude. If A_hat < 1, the shear signal is genuinely suppressed relative to theory.
fibers.outcome: The chi2 degradation with z is a secondary symptom. The primary finding is that shear × κ is NOT detected at all: A_lens = 0.06 ± 0.05 (joint, 19σ from unity). Both map and catalog estimators agree. The chi2 increases with z because theory amplitude grows while data remains at zero. See shear-non-detection-7070539d for the full investigation.

fibers.title: RR2 shear response correction
fibers.body:
## Question for Margherita/Giulio

Shear × CMB κ cross-correlation gives A_lens ≈ 0.1 (consistent with zero, 18-19σ from unity) for both lensmc and metacal, both map and catalog estimators. Meanwhile density × κ gives A_lens = 1.05 ± 0.06, confirming the pipeline works for spin-0.

### Key questions

1. **Does `she_{method}_e1_corrected` already include the shear response/calibration correction?** In standard metacal, `e_corrected` is the PSF-corrected ellipticity NOT divided by the shear response <R>. The true shear estimate requires γ = <e>/<R>. If this correction is missing, our cross-spectra are suppressed by <R>.

2. **What is the expected value of <R> for this catalog?** For metacal with the RR2 resolution (r2/(r2+psf_r2) ≈ 0.74) and S/N (median 92), typical <R> should be 0.6-0.8. But our measured A ≈ 0.1 would require <R> ≈ 0.1, which seems inconsistent with well-resolved galaxies.

3. **Has anyone measured shear 2-point statistics (γγ) from RR2?** The SHE validation talk (Sept 2025) mentions "first unblinded cosmological constraints" — if shear auto-power shows cosmological signal, the catalog does contain shear information and our issue is in the cross-correlation.

4. **For lensmc**: The forward-modeling pipeline directly estimates the shear. Is `e_corrected` the raw model-fit ellipticity, or has it been calibrated? The talk shows |m| ~ 2×10⁻³ — but that's from sim comparison. Does the catalog value of e_corrected already fold in that correction?

### Context

All calibration columns (m11/m12/m21/m22, c1/c2, weight_cal) are NaN for all 30.7M galaxies. We use `e1_corrected`, `e2_corrected` with `she_{method}_weight` directly.

Run `snakemake -n` to see the cascade size, then `snakemake -j20` to execute. After completion, verify:
1. Per-spectrum evidence JSON shows excess S/N (shear should be near zero, density 3-16)
2. Redshift trend plots show corrected labels
3. Signal overview shows corrected panel titles
4. Results table reflects new numbers

The smk-070912 session (plot/likelihood rebuild from iteration 11) may still be running or recently completed. Its outputs used OLD evidence and will be stale again.

fibers.title: NaMaster Gaussian as primary covariance
fibers.body:
NaMaster Gaussian covariance (iNKA) agrees with Knox within 25% for 19/20 bandpowers (median ratio 1.04 density, 1.26 shear). But the last bandpower (ℓ≈2700) has NaMaster variance ~1000× smaller than Knox — a coupling matrix numerical artifact at the edge of the ℓ range. Currently the pipeline works around this by using Knox for all chi2/PTE/A_lens, but that's the wrong solution: NaMaster should be primary for everything, and the last-bandpower issue should be diagnosed and fixed.

**Questions to answer:**
1. Is the artifact specific to our masks, or general to NaMaster at high ℓ near lmax?
2. Does trimming the last bandpower (or shifting ℓ_max down slightly) eliminate it?
3. Does using a different binning scheme (linear vs log-spaced) change the behavior?
4. Are the coupling matrix singular values pathological only in the last bin?

**Desired state:** NaMaster Gaussian covariance is primary for all quantitative inference — chi2, PTE, A_lens, S/N, likelihood input. Knox becomes a cross-check only.

The old pipeline worked because nmt_utils used pol_conv=COSMO (accidental correct result on IAU maps). Commit a26e21b switched to pol_conv=IAU (correct label, but _apply_pol_conv did nothing for IAU). Fix applied to spectra.py. Needs: recompute all shear cross-spectra, verify A_lens recovers.

fibers.title: Recompute shear after pol_conv fix
fibers.body:
## What to do

1. **Re-install dr1_cmbx** — the pol_conv fix (commit 4195faf on maps_refactor) must be in the installed package. Run `pip install -e code/dr1_cmbx` or equivalent in the container.

2. **Touch compute_cross_spectrum.py** — snakemake won't see library changes. Add a comment or trivial change to trigger script-hash rebuild.

3. **Dry run** — `snakemake -n compute_all_shear_cross_spectra` should show all shear jobs need rebuilding. Also `compute_all_systematic_cross_spectra` (shear × systematic) needs rebuilding.

4. **Run** — `snakemake-tmux -j20 compute_all_shear_cross_spectra compute_all_systematic_cross_spectra`

5. **Verify** — Check A_lens for lensmc × ACT. Should recover to ≈ 1, not ≈ 0.

6. **Cascade** — After shear xspec rebuild: combine rules, likelihood, plots, results table all need regeneration. Run the default target or `generate_results_table`.

7. **Update fibers** — Close shear-non-detection fiber with revised outcome. Update findings synthesis. The "11 ruled-out hypotheses" were all correct — the bug was in the pol_conv machinery, not any of those.

fibers.title: FITS to pickle migration
fibers.body:
Collaborators want shear and density maps stored as pickle to match the `dr1_cmbx` library format (`wl_cat2map()`/`gc_cat2map()`). Currently our pipeline writes sparse FITS via `write_sparse_map()` — one file per (method, bin). The migration matches the dr1_cmbx convention: one pickle per method, all bins nested inside. Also adds a `core` target for lean verification runs (~60 jobs instead of 500+).

## Scope

**Migrate to pickle**: Shear maps (build_maps.py), density maps (build_density_maps.py), jackknife null maps (build_jackknife_null_maps.py).

**Keep as FITS**: Apodized masks (dense HEALPix, NaMaster idiom). External inputs (ACT/SPT/systematic maps).

**Add core target**: maps + masks + cross-spectra + combine + likelihood = A_lens. Default snakemake target.

## Pickle Format

Match dr1_cmbx `wl_cat2map()` structure. One pickle per method, all bins nested:

```python
# Shear: {method}_maps.pkl
{
    "7bin": {
        "bin0": {  # 0-indexed to match dr1_cmbx
            "ipix": np.array,        # sparse pixel indices (RING)
            "e1": np.array,          # weighted mean shear per pixel
            "e2": np.array,          # weighted mean shear per pixel
            "sum_weights": np.array, # sum(w) per pixel
            "neff": np.array,        # effective N per pixel
            "mask": np.array,        # binary (all 1.0, sparse)
            "noise_cl": float,       # flat shape noise
            "fsky": float,
            "sigma_eps": float,
            "sigma_eps_comp": float,
            "n_eff_global": float,
            "nmean_srad": float,
            "c1_sub": float,
            "c2_sub": float,
            "pol_conv": "IAU",
        },
        "bin1": {...},
        ...
        "bin6": {...},  # "all" bin stored as bin6 (last)
    }
}

# Density: density_maps.pkl
{
    "7bin": {
        "bin0": {
            "ipix": np.array,
            "map": np.array,      # overdensity delta (sparse)
            "mask": np.array,     # binary mask (sparse)
            "n_gal": int,
            "n_gal_sr": float,
            "area_sr": float,
            "shot_nl": float,
            "nmean": float,
        },
        ...
    }
}
```

## Read-Side: Inline pickle loads

No helper function — inline `pickle.load()` + sparse-to-dense, same as spectra.py line 1087:

```python
data = pickle.load(open(pkl_path, "rb"))
bin_key = next(k for k in data if k.endswith("bin"))
bd = data[bin_key][f"bin{bin_idx}"]
npix = hp.nside2npix(nside)
e1 = np.zeros(npix); e1[bd["ipix"]] = bd["e1"]
```

## Files to Modify

### Write side (3 scripts)
1. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_build_maps.py` — All bins in one invocation, single pickle.dump()
2. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_build_density_maps.py` — Same pattern
3. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_build_jackknife_null_maps.py` — Convert to pickle output

### Rules (DAG structure changes)
4. `cmbx/files/workflow_rules_maps.smk` — Remove {bin} wildcard from catalog_to_map and build_density_map
5. `workflow/Snakefile` — get_euclid_map_files() returns pkl path + bin_id param. Add core rule.
6. `cmbx/files/workflow_rules_spectra.smk` — Update compute_cross_spectrum inputs/params
7. `cmbx/files/workflow_rules_explorations.smk` — Update ~15 FITS path references
8. `cmbx/files/workflow_rules_tapestry.smk` — Update map input paths

### Read side (~12 scripts) — inline pickle.load() + sparse-to-dense
9. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_compute_cross_spectrum.py`
10. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_compute_systematic_cross_spectrum.py`
11. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_build_apodized_pair_masks.py` (read pickle, still write FITS masks)
12. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_build_rr2_apodized_masks.py`
13. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_euclid_rr2_maps.py`
14. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_shear_maps.py`
15. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_systematic_maps.py`
16. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_cmb_lensing_doc.py`
17. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_cmb_lensing_maps.py`
18. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_shared_map_conventions.py`
19. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_build_overlap_masks.py`
20. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_compute_global_vlims.py`
21. `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_diagnose_coupling_matrix.py`

### Params propagation
Rules consuming map pickles need bin_id passed as a param (or from wildcards) so scripts know which bin to load.

## Core Target

```python
rule core:
    """Lean pipeline: maps -> cross-spectra -> combine -> likelihood -> A_lens."""
    input:
        expand(..., method=all_methods, bin=all_bins, cmbk=cmbk_baseline),
        expand(... shear sacc ..., cmbk=cmbk_baseline),
        expand(... density sacc ..., cmbk=cmbk_baseline),
        expand(... fiducial likelihood ..., cmbk=cmbk_baseline),
```

~60 jobs: maps (3 map jobs) -> masks -> ~42 cross-spectra -> combine -> likelihood -> A_lens.

## Execution Order

1. Write-side scripts (build_maps.py, build_density_maps.py, build_jackknife_null_maps.py)
2. Rules (maps.smk, Snakefile path functions, spectra.smk)
3. Read-side scripts (compute_cross_spectrum.py first, then others)
4. Core rule in Snakefile
5. explorations.smk and remaining scripts
6. Dry run core target
7. Run core, verify A_lens

## Verification

1. `snakemake -n core` shows ~60 jobs
2. Pickle structure matches dr1_cmbx: `python -c "import pickle; d = pickle.load(open('path.pkl','rb')); print(d.keys())"`
3. A_lens ~ 1 for density x ACT (confirms pol_conv fix + pickle roundtrip)
4. A_lens for shear x ACT (the big question — should recover from ~0)

All 21 read-side scripts converted to load from pickle (np.load → pickle.load with bin indexing). Jackknife null maps also converted (commit 8942a74). Core target added (~84 jobs for lean verification). Pipeline verified end-to-end: maps→masks→xspec→likelihood→A_lens with pol_conv fix. Apodized masks remain FITS (NaMaster idiom). Four commits: 493dacb (write side), 15301ce (read side + core), 8942a74 (jackknife), 7f0a4cc (pol_conv).

fibers.title: Shear sign convention test
fibers.body:
After the pol_conv fix (commit 4195faf) and pickle migration, shear A_lens = -0.88 (lensmc×ACT). Correct magnitude (~1), wrong sign. Density A_lens = 1.049 (correct, unaffected).

The chain: catalog e1,e2 (IAU) → pickle → make_field with pol_conv=IAU → _apply_pol_conv flips e2 → NaMaster gets [e1, -e2]. Result: A_lens ≈ -0.88.

Now testing [-e1, +e2] with pol_conv=COSMO (no library flip). Build running in smk-140111 (53 jobs). If A_lens recovers to ~+1, that is the correct convention.

| Convention | e1 | e2 | A_lens (lensmc×ACT) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Old (broken pol_conv) | +e1 | +e2 | ≈ 0.06 |
| pol_conv fix | +e1 | -e2 | ≈ -0.88 |
| Test: flip e1 | -e1 | +e2 | pending |
fibers.outcome:
Resolved. Euclid catalogs define position angle from West toward North — distinct from both standard IAU (North toward East) and HEALPix COSMO (South toward East). The 90° offset from IAU means (e1,e2)_Euclid = -(e1,e2)_stdIAU. The correct NaMaster mapping is [-e1, +e2], implemented as pol_conv='EUCLID' in dr1_cmbx spectra.py (maps_refactor). Result: lensmc×ACT A_lens = 0.88 ± 0.052 (17σ, PTE=0.72), metacal×ACT = 0.85 ± 0.055 (15σ, PTE=0.57). The convention table:
  COSMO (θ from South, right-handed): [e1, e2] → NaMaster native
  IAU (θ from North, left-handed): [e1, -e2] → flip e2
  Euclid (θ from West, left-handed): [-e1, +e2] → flip e1

fibers.title: Contamination pyramid
fibers.body:
Three-tier contamination visualization pyramid, all implemented and polished.

## Tier 1: X hero plot (DONE — polished)
Rule: `plot_contamination_overview`. 2×11 grid (density vs shear columns, 11 sysmap rows). X^f_S = C^{κS} · C^{fS} / C^{SS} (Chang+ 2203.12440, Eq. A.4.1) with propagated Knox error bars. Layout: per-subplot titles, FW-scale columns, margins in inches. Methods by linestyle+marker, color by CMB experiment. Compact rows (1.8"), larger markers, solid zero line. Fiber: `contamination-overview-created-91247caa`.

## Tier 2: PTE heatmap (DONE — polished)
Rule: `plot_pte_heatmap`. 11×18 matshow (sysmaps × 3 tracers × 6 bins). Vlag colormap with saturated tails (SaturatedTailNorm clamps PTE < 0.05 and > 0.95). Density 0/66 pass (expected — galaxy positions correlate with survey depth). LensMC 56/66 pass (85%). Metacal 57/66 pass (86%). Caveat: NaMaster Gaussian error bars unvalidated for these spectra. Fiber: `pte-heatmap-created-97147114`.

## Tier 3: Ingredient breakdowns (DONE)
Rule: `plot_systematic_spectra`. 3-panel per sysmap: C^{fS} (all methods), C^{κS} (ACT + SPT), C^{SS} (auto per footprint). 11 figures. Fiber: `systematic-spectra-raw-c-fs-c-3d65264d`.

## Error propagation on X
σ²(X) = (C^{fS}/C^{SS})² · σ²(C^{κS}) + (C^{κS}/C^{SS})² · σ²(C^{fS}). Knox variances from NPZ files. C^{SS} noise bias at high ℓ makes X a lower bound. Chang+ used jackknife (65-85 patches) for X errors; we use Knox propagation — reasonable since C^{κS} and C^{fS} are independent field combinations.

## Open: noise bias in C^{SS}
Auto-spectrum C^{SS} includes pixel noise at high ℓ (no splits available for noise debiasing). X is a known lower bound. Noted in figure caption.

fibers.title: Contamination overview created
fibers.body:
The contamination overview is the hero figure of the systematic validation — a single plot showing X^f_S = C^{κS} · C^{fS} / C^{SS} (Chang+ 2023, `docs/arxiv/2203.12440`, Eq. A.4.1) for all 11 systematic maps across both tracer types. X^f_S has the same units as the signal C^{fκ}, so a direct comparison tells us how much each systematic biases the measurement per bandpower.

## Layout

2 columns (density, shear) × 11 rows (sysmaps). Density column shows ACT + SPT (2 curves). Shear column shows lensmc×ACT, metacal×ACT, lensmc×SPT, metacal×SPT (4 curves). Each subplot has its own title: "{Sysmap} × {Tracer}". Methods are distinguished by both linestyle (solid=lensmc, dashed=metacal) and marker (circle=lensmc, square=metacal); color encodes CMB experiment (salmon=ACT, teal=SPT) from the shared `COLORS` dict.

## Error bars

Propagated from Knox formula: σ²(X) is computed from the Knox covariance of C^{κS} and C^{fS}. C^{SS} is noise-biased at high ℓ (see `systematic-spectra-raw-c-fs-c-3d65264d`), so X is a lower bound on true contamination.

## Implementation

Rule: `plot_contamination_overview` (explorations.smk, localrule — reads pre-computed NPZ). Script: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_contamination_overview.py`. Evidence: `cmbx/files/results_claims_plot_contamination_overview_evidence.json`. Polished in `contamination-overview-polished-f12338e4`.

fibers.title: Tapestry early-mid polish
fibers.body:
Lovingly improve the early-to-mid tapestry: systematic contamination figures, signal overview, SPT estimator comparison. Polish plots to presentation quality for CMBX-SWG internal audience, and enrich fiber bodies with traceable, referenced descriptions. After plots are implemented, iterations should alternate between visual refinement and fiber content.

## Desired State

### Infrastructure: tapestry aggregate target

A snakemake rule `tapestry` that collects ALL active `tapestry:`-tagged fiber rules into one target. Implementation: query `felt ls -t tapestry:` at DAG construction time or maintain a list in the Snakefile. When `snakemake tapestry` runs clean, the full tapestry is up to date.

### 1. Contamination overview (X plot)
`plot_contamination_overview` — 2×11 grid showing X^f_S per systematic map.

- **Each subplot has its own title**: "{Sysmap} × {Tracer}" (e.g., "Persistence × Galaxy density"). No suptitle, no column headers.
- **One y-axis label per row** on the left column only. Right column panels suppress the y-axis label.
- **Figure dimensions computed from content**, not hardcoded. Margins (left, right, top, bottom) in inches, not figure fractions — so they scale correctly regardless of row count.
- **lensmc vs metacal visually distinct**: BOTH linestyle (solid vs dashed) AND marker shape (circle vs square). Color encodes CMB experiment (ACT salmon, SPT teal from COLORS dict). So: lensmc×ACT = solid+circle+salmon, metacal×ACT = dashed+square+salmon, lensmc×SPT = solid+circle+teal, metacal×SPT = dashed+square+teal.
- Legend in one panel (top-right) showing all curve styles.
- Figure should be slightly narrower than current — `FW`-scale columns, not `FW + 0.5`.

### 2. PTE heatmap (new figure)
New rule `plot_pte_heatmap`. Axes: sysmap (rows) × tomographic bin (columns), one panel per tracer×cmbk combination.

- Colored by PTE from existing systematic null test evidence.
- **Colormap**: `vlag` (diverging), `vmin=0, vmax=1`. To make failures pop: clip the colormap so that PTE < 0.05 maps to the extreme red and PTE > 0.95 maps to the extreme blue — i.e., the 0→0.05 and 0.95→1 tails are saturated flat color. Implementation: `matplotlib.colors.TwoSlopeNorm(vcenter=0.5, vmin=0, vmax=1)` with the vlag cmap, or manually build a clipped norm that compresses the tails. `set_bad(lightgray)` for missing. Reference: `sp_validation/src/sp_validation/b_modes.py:751-782` (uses vlag + contour at 0.05/0.95; adapt for heatmap).
- Annotate each cell with PTE value (2 decimal places).
- **Caveat in fiber and plot**: error bars are not yet validated — PTE pass/fail may reflect error bar mis-estimation rather than true contamination. Frame as "preliminary diagnostic" not "verdict."
- Data source: per-bin NPZ in `results/.../systematics/{sysmap}_x_{method}_bin{n}_cls.npz`. Look for `chi2_dof` and `pte` fields; if absent, compute from chi2 and dof inline using scipy.stats.chi2.sf.

### 3. Systematic spectra (ingredient breakdowns)
`plot_systematic_spectra` — one figure per sysmap (11 total), 3 panels: C^{fS}, C^{κS}, C^{SS}.

fibers.title: PTE heatmap created
fibers.body:
A single-glance diagnostic showing which systematic × tracer × tomographic bin combinations pass the null test. The heatmap displays PTE (probability to exceed) from the χ² test of C^{fS}_ℓ = 0 for each cell. Red cells (PTE < 0.05) indicate the measured cross-spectrum is unlikely to be noise; blue cells (PTE > 0.95) would indicate anomalously low scatter. This complements the contamination overview (X^f_S) by testing whether the *tracer* side of the contamination chain is consistent with zero, independently of the CMB κ side.

## Layout

11 rows (sysmaps) × 18 columns (3 tracers × 6 tomographic bins). Colormap: `vlag` (diverging, red–blue) with saturated tails — PTE < 0.05 maps to the same extreme red (all failures identical), PTE > 0.95 to extreme blue, interior [0.05, 0.95] spans the full color range. Cells annotated by PTE value (2 decimal places). Missing data in light gray.

## Results

- **Density**: 0/66 pass (all PTE = 0.00). Expected — galaxy positions physically correlate with survey depth, stellar density, etc. This is not a failure of the analysis; it confirms the maps contain real structure.
- **LensMC**: 56/66 pass (85%). Failures in galactic extinction, galaxy number density, and persistence at specific bins (2, 5, 6).
- **Metacal**: 57/66 pass (86%). Similar failure pattern to lensmc.

## Caveat

Error bars use NaMaster Gaussian covariance, which is not yet validated for tracer × sysmap cross-spectra. The PTE pass/fail rates may reflect error bar mis-estimation rather than true contamination. This heatmap should be read as a preliminary diagnostic, not a definitive verdict. See `namaster-gaussian-covariance-9373b1fa` for covariance validation status.

## Implementation

Rule: `plot_pte_heatmap` (explorations.smk, localrule). Script: `cmbx/files/workflow_scripts_plot_pte_heatmap.py`. Evidence: `cmbx/files/results_claims_plot_pte_heatmap_evidence.json`.
fibers.outcome: New rule plot_pte_heatmap: 11x18 matshow (sysmaps x tracers*bins). Density 0/66 pass (all PTE=0.00, expected — galaxy positions correlate with survey depth). LensMC 56/66 pass (85%). Metacal 57/66 pass (86%). Shear failures scattered across galactic extinction, galaxy_number_density, persistence bins 2/5/6. Error bars not yet validated — PTE may reflect covariance mis-estimation.

fibers.title: Catalog covariance falls back to Knox
fibers.body:
compute_cross_spectrum.py silently falls back to Knox variance when NaMaster Gaussian covariance can't be computed for the catalog estimator. The catalog path hits 'no theory or pseudo-Cl for covariance' (line 470) because the catalog Knox proxy sets compute_knox=False before the NaMaster covariance block runs, and the guess spectra require pcl_11/pcl_22 from the Knox result which the catalog proxy doesn't provide.

Result: map NPZ has both cov (NaMaster) and knox_var; catalog NPZ has only knox_var. The Knox variances themselves differ by ~3x (catalog uses cruder fsky estimate). This means error bars in the catalog vs map comparison plot are inconsistent between the two estimators.

Fix: ensure the catalog code path builds NaMaster Gaussian covariance using the auxiliary map-based NmtField (which already exists for this purpose). The guess spectra can come from the map-based field's pseudo-Cl. Should also audit all other silent Knox fallbacks — user preference is to never silently degrade from NaMaster to Knox.
fibers.outcome: Fixed: added theory_npz and cmb_noise_curve params to compute_catalog_cross_spectrum rule (explorations.smk). Catalog estimator now uses theory+noise guess spectra for NaMaster Gaussian covariance — same path as map estimator. Silent fallback replaced with RuntimeError. All 70/70 catalog NPZ files now have NaMaster cov (was Knox-only). Old workspace cache (98GB) deleted to free disk.

If NaMaster can't be computed, raise an error or explicitly log a WARNING that the user must acknowledge. fibers.title: Evidence auto-glob inflates output count
fibers.body:
`aggregate_evidence.py` lines 523-529 auto-detect all PNGs in the claims directory and register them as outputs:

```python
for ext in (".png", ".pdf", ".jpg", ".jpeg"):
    for f in sorted(claims_dir.glob(f"*{ext}")):
        output_dict[f.stem] = f.name
```

This picks up stale artifacts from old script versions (e.g. per-method PNGs that the script no longer produces). Fix: either (a) only register outputs that match the current rule's snakemake outputs, or (b) have each per-wildcard evidence.json declare its own output PNG, and the aggregate collects only declared outputs.

Immediate mitigation: cleaned stale per-method PNGs from `plot_systematic_spectra` claims dir (39 files), reducing evidence output count from 45 → 12. But `plot_contamination_metric` still has 121 outputs from this glob pattern.
